Citigroup Inc, Research Division - MD and Director

Presentation

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA, HEAD OF IR, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted] Good morning. Good morning, today, guests. Hello. We are beginning. Guests are still arriving. It is early morning in Moscow. We know that we are being watched on webcast across the different geographies, so good morning to all of you. Good time of the day.

We have a very intensive program today. You will note that this is a regular event that we hold every year to briefly discuss the business outcomes of the previous 12 months. And the outlook for the next year of 2020, this time, we're going to share our perspectives with you. We've got 13 speakers today, a very intensive program. We're going to start with a brief overview on strategy. It will be done by Senior Vice President, Yulia Chupina. After that, we're going to discuss the core banking business. The First Deputy Chief Executive Officer Alexander Vedyakhin is going to talk about that. Then we're going to have 2 deep dives into corporate business and into wealth management by Anatoly Popov and Natalya Alymova. After that, we're going to adjourn for a coffee break, and then it's going to be a progress of the tech program -- platform. David Rafalovsky is going to do that. And then it's going to be a full-blown discussion of the ecosystem. The First Deputy CEO Lev Khasis is going to talk. And several chief executive officers of the companies that already are or will be soon in our ecosystem, we're talking Yandex. Market, Rambler, DC and Citymobil. A brief lunch will follow. And then we are going to discuss the prospects for 2020 with the Chief of our Macro Analysis Division, the other executives, the Chief Financial Officer, who are going to speak about the trends and financial indicators, Oleg Zamulin, Dzhangir Dzhangirov and Alexander Morozov are going to cover that bit of the day.

First off, right off the bat, we're going to have a brief Q&A for all the speakers, and there's going to be 2 big Q&A sessions for the outcomes of the ecosystem discussion and the forecast discussion. The working language is Russian. If you didn't get a simultaneous translation set, please take it. Raise your hand, we're going to help you with that.

Mobile phones, the disclaimer are obviously the same. I'm not going to waste the time on housekeeping. Let's roll. And have a good day.

ALEXANDER VLADIMIROVICH MOROZOV, DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD & CFO, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted] Yes, one more important comment to make. Good day, colleagues. Good day, guests.

There's going to be a slight change in our agenda. To save on time, we're going to cut short the lunch a little bit. Hopefully, we're going to catch up with the time to finish off about 1 hour, maybe 1.5 hours earlier than we originally envisaged. Hopefully, we're going to be able to accomplish that. And will obviously give you more time to write your reports, so don't you worry. Hopefully, by at least 15:00, perhaps even earlier, we're going to finish this event.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] And with that, I would like to invite Ms. Chupina, Yulia Germanovna Chupina, our Chief Strategist and a Senior Vice President of the bank.

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA, SVP, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted] Thank you, Stasia. Good morning, all. Thank you very much for your choice to start this wonderful, sunny, fresh morning in Moscow, to start it with us. Thank you for that. I will need the clicker, and there it is. It is a great joy for everyone. Hopefully, we are still your favorite stock.

And if my talk is to be boiled down to one phrase, we are good on strategy. I'm going to dive deep into details, but this is perhaps the most important takeaway from that. We are delivering on strategy. You will probably remember a lot of criticisms leveled against our critic -- against our market. But in terms of the market, in terms of the margins, in terms of the returns, it's one of the most attractive markets in the world. And when we wrote that strategy, we were actually a little bit more conservative than we should have been on all the banking markets. We have a slightly better growth and a slightly better margin than we had originally envisaged. You will remember that our strategy was about not just being one of the best and perhaps one of the most relevant financial institutions in the Russian market, we started building a big ecosystem around our core business. So the first part was about our best customer experience in finance and in other customer needs. The second big topic of the strategy was tech leadership. The third was strengthening our team. And we believe that if we deliver on all the 3, we're going to arrive at a great financial performance, which is actually happening.

I'm going to show you these boxes checked, where we are either spot on with the strategy targets or we are a bit off. If there are any nuances, I'm going to talk about those. You will remember that we gave the guidance of the market shares, and we aimed to stay with the same market shares, where we started with that strategy period. It is exactly what has been happening. Perhaps we have been a bit slow in growing the lending to corporates because we took a conscious path to maintain our margin. The same goes for the individuals' market share on deposits with individuals. That said, we launched a pretty broad array of products, for instance, in the retail. I would specifically highlight the products that will again become the very important benchmark for the entire system. First off, we can now disburse a loan in 2 minutes without actually asking a person any questions. There are obvious limitations when we don't ask any questions. These are generally our payroll customers. But in terms of automation, you will appreciate that this is a good new product, these are all good new products. And then we keep adding financial products to our ecosystem companies, for instance, in Peru, the marketplace. You can take a POS loan. We continue developing DomClick, everything around the mortgage. Most of our customers can now enjoy a lot of attended products.

We launched a new card. It is a fully digital card. And we think that this is a highly promising product. You can activate this card online without getting any physical representation of it. You can actually start transacting with that electronic card.

Perhaps another important thing -- innovation for our customers was having centralized everything. The customer can now enjoy our capability to be served anywhere with no any difference where he originally got connected. We launched the QR code-based payments, cross-border payments. These were all important products.

And you may have heard about the regular awards that we have been getting in Russia, in the world, in Europe. And we think that this is the right recognition to be aiming for, the recognition of our conventional and innovative products alike.

As for the corporate business, you know that this was an important year for us to start financing construction along the new lines we now have escrow accounts. We can also lend to SMEs, small and medium enterprises, in 10 minutes. That is already a possibility. We launched a whole lineup of business cards that is commercial cards for business. We have actually products that have been helping Russia to become more attractive as a place for doing business, for instance, VAT recovery. It used to take 180 days. Now it takes 7 days.

And this year, there's a whole new segment in Russia and in Sberbank, and we have been actively working with it. This is a segment of self -- of the self-employed, the self-employed people as well as private entrepreneurs.

We have been developing those electronic channels actively. This is a worldwide trend. We have in excess of 15 million customers in Sberbank Online. You can see the growth in the ratio down of MAU, daily average users -- monthly average users, in retail and in corporate businesses better than competition. Over 40% in both the businesses have been happening online, and between 80% to 100% of services, again, are used online. Having said that, we relaunched our corporate Sberbank Online as SBOL. And we intend to continue with the digital upgrade, the digital revamp of the application.

You will hear a lot about the ecosystem. Guys are going to come in front of you from all our new businesses. It's always great to see all of them.

Let me remind you about why we are doing this. We think that the future of banking is going to be changing materially. We don't want to become a commodity. It's very important for us to keep that last mile of the relationship with the customer. We want our customers to be served by us as much as we can digitally and physically. Although about 90% of our transactions are still the financial business, but we are adding on all kinds of things, all kinds of new occasions where we can close some kind of need of a customer, where we can serve some kind of a need of a customer.

In this box, you can see our big partnerships and acquisitions. Basically, we are following the needs of the customers that are well presented in this slide. This is a slide from the strategy. You may remember the way we identified the time that customers or companies spend in getting served and the frequency of getting served, the size of the potential business was chartered here as the various industries are interested -- that the customers are interested in.

The bright green -- I beg your pardon, the blue is what Sberbank used to cover. And this is where we are at the end of 2019. There's much more coverage. We are striving to make customers to spend more time with us much more. So they don't have to go anywhere outside this ecosystem.

Why is this important? It is important because our branches have been gradually transformed. There's increasingly fewer people in branches. The foot traffic is going down, which is good in terms of digital channels because that is better cost of service. But then we appreciate that this is still an asset to retain. It needs to be depreciated. And because we are getting new products, we understand that we can reload this asset with more work.

And then we appreciate our social responsibility in Russia as a big employer. Not only are we keen to increase the financial literacy of the population, as a long term, working with branches would be the right thing to do because that is a touch point for the entire nation and for the business.

Appreciably, there are some big names with some several million clients. Our ecosystem spans e-commerce, that is our JV with Yandex. Market; that's Delivery Club; that's Citymobil; ALCO; the video streaming service, Rambler. Those are all the digital services that we are using to bundle up with financial products, and we intend to retain the customer retention and frequency of touch points with customers.

That said, we make a lot of circles in the market when we buy something. But if you juxtapose the value of those investments with the core business, those are not important amounts, except perhaps for the 2 that Lev is going to talk about. Those gave us access to promising markets. They gave us access to customers, to data. And you will appreciate that you can do a lot with data and especially if you know how to do that.

In terms of the tech leadership, there are things for us to finish in the platform. You know that we have been investing long and a lot into the tech retooling of the bank. This year, we can positively say that the new platform is viable because Sberbank Online is now fully on it. The front capability of it is there. The back office for that is, again, revolving around the customer. Again, it's there. It used to be about products. Now it's about full knowledge of the customer, and there's 21 products there.

We launched a big data factory that supports reporting, that helps manage all the data flows in the bank. And there's a superstructure of analytical platform above the data factory. So all our AI analysts can have a repository for the models and tune up those models pretty quickly.

And there's another big initiative that we launched this year, and we're going to continue developing it next year. That's our cloud. You certainly know that Russia is behind on the number of businesses in the cloud. We see a great promise in using cloud capabilities for ourselves and our customers alike. We have launched a lot of projects where third-party customers use our cloud capability for their business.

Finally, we can now -- we can positively say that we are an omnichannel business. All our branches are going to be working on an application that is going to be very similar to SBOL, Sberbank Online, and all the front and the back are going to be the same.

And thanks to these technological innovations, thanks to transitioning all this -- all our organization into agile together with IT, we decreased the time to market 7x. We are now much quicker in deploying -- in developing and deploying products and services. Having said that, the capacity of the platform are spot on, on the parameters that we planned for when we launched all those programs. Perhaps one of the most -- we're probably one of the most efficient and effective banks in terms of cybersecurity. There was one big, high-profile case of internal fraud that was broadly covered. We still have been funding pretty much all of the attacks that we got subjected to. We now learned the hard way about the need to protect ourselves internally from the internal fraud, and we are actively working to prevent social engineering.

AI transformation is, again, a reality given the new platform. It's important for the AI models to be built into the products and services. We now have about 25 propositions to customers done in real time. And next year, the guys run the figures, about RUB 1 billion is going to be -- about $1 billion is going to be earned by AI initiatives. I mentioned the NLP platform, natural language processing, AI cloud. You may have read that we're going to be helping not just ourselves but the nation at large. Together with all the companies in the consortium, we're going to be pursuing the AI strategy because we appreciate that AI is going to change everything dramatically, not just the banking industry, and we want to help Russia to be one of the leaders in the area.

And all of that is obviously done by people. They are essential for the success of all that. We set ourselves a lot of objectives in changing how we work with people, how we attract talent, how we develop leaders that work in our organization. And it's a big organization, 300,000 strong, and it can actually become bigger. If you tally in all the couriers and drivers from all the new businesses, there's going to be interesting things to happen next year in HR, how do you work with this big, bulging team. And we do a lot of things to make HR more technological because we think that a lot of processes can be done automatically and can be centralized.

Because there's a big shortage of qualified employees nationwide, we launched initiatives to prepare talent not just for ourselves, but for the market. That's School 21. They train coders, IT guys. Next year, we're going to develop -- we're going to open a design school because product design is another competency in short supply. And we decided to develop our own HR platform because we think that SAP and success factors are not the cutting-edge products that could be in market.

We spoke about agile. All the headquarters -- all the HQs working in HR, all the finance guys, business people, you name it, they are in HR -- they are in agile. Besides the accelerated time to market, that new culture, the agile culture is giving a new framework, a new culture of developing software. About 90% is being done as a DevOps effort. HR -- agile is doing everything more transparent, and we continue to improve the tools. How do we see all the way deep down to the budget of every support to the speed with which they develop the code, how reliable that code is. And next year, we're going to unify, standardize these practices for the group, including all the new ecosystem companies.

The traditional question to hear at one of these days is the headcount. We launched the strategy with 90,000. We cut about 30,000 in the transactions where we could automate, in business efficiency. We added about 15,000 people in the initiatives that we need to become a tech company. These are primarily IT specialists, these are data scientists, these are product designers, and these are the ecosystem companies.

So we think that in general, we have a more balanced situation now, a more balanced team that is needed for the future technology development of the future. And our network has become 15% more efficient, so that means that with the same amount of people, we do more business.

In terms of the financial performance, we're going to discuss that in great detail today. But anyway, in a nutshell, we are delivering on all our commitments, and we hope that you appreciate that, you appreciate our dividends and ROE.

So basically, that is it. I'm ready to answer the questions.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Thank you very much, Yulia. Colleagues, please, questions. So please raise your hand, introduce yourself and make -- and say the question. Alan, please.

Questions and Answers

ALAN RAMSEY WEBBORN, EQUITY ANALYST, SOCIETE GENERALE CROSS ASSET RESEARCH: You're talking about the sort of omnichannel branches and/or system. And you've mentioned a new branch sort of strategy. And you've talked actually more certainly than probably last year about the linkage between online and branches. And why is that now? Is it because you feel that you are not maximizing the revenues from clients who are still reluctant to go fully online? I feel that there's a slight change from last year. So what's behind that thinking? And could you perhaps just expand a little bit more on what you mean about this sort of new branch sort of policy and strategy?

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: Well, first of all, we now have the opportunity to be omnichannel because without the new platform, we didn't have that opportunity. So I think this is the major change which happened this year, and it will be fully implemented next year. So the client coming to our office can continue the operation online in his mobile application or go into call center, and it will be the same kind of data that our employee will see, and he can basically have that omnichannel experience, which was the target of the Strategy 2020. So this is one.

The second one, we're obviously looking around the world, and we think that now it's sort of proven that all the technological companies, even those that started digital, decided that online to offline is the most interesting combination. So that's why you would see Amazon and others purchasing offline branches.

And for us, we just discussed it a lot in between ourselves whether we see that the offline would be as efficient as digital. And we think it will be because of several reasons. One is we want the client to come to whatever channel that is convenient because we want this last-mile relationship with the client. And once again, you know that even in developed world, there are still clients who want to go to the branch for different reasons, and we want to give him this opportunity.

Second, the next year, you will see the new product range launched into branches from the companies of our ecosystem. So if today mostly the branches are selling financial products and mostly banking, I would say, next year, it would be nonbanking financial products and also ecosystem products. So that would drive the branches' efficiency up.

And thirdly, it's the question that you were asking every year, like how many branches are you going to keep and how many people, so I just decided to put it straight away in the presentation. You know where our thinking is. Next year, we will be writing our new strategy for the next 3 years. And the usage of channel will be one of the discussions in terms of how do we build our ecosystem. You know that there are different approaches, whether to let some of the competitors be with us or some of the partners be with us, but this is the discussion for the next year.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: Gabor?

GABOR ZOLTAN KEMENY, RESEARCH ANALYST, AUTONOMOUS RESEARCH LLP: It's Gabor Kemeny from Autonomous Research. A question on this AI transformation. You mentioned, I think a $1 billion additional impact in 2020. In what form shall we expect this to come through? Do you see this as additional revenues from product sales, from fee-generating businesses, potential cost savings? A little more color would be helpful.

And in your corporate lending market share, you mentioned that you lost some of the corporate lending market share recently. Do you expect this to continue?

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: Well, let me start with the first, and my friend and colleague, Alexander Vedyakhin, will definitely help me on both as the Head of Business and the Head of AI Transformation as well.

On the market share, let me be very explicit here. You can see that we started the strategy with 32% of the market, and we are here with 31%, so I wouldn't call it the loss of the market. I would call it the strategy which is -- which allows us to keep the margins. So we are not going for the loans which are -- which give us less profitability that we want to. You know that it depends on the borrower and the possibilities he has. So we are very conscious of going for good borrows with good profitability but also with good risk profile. So it's not that we are losing market, it's we are keeping the market more or less the same. We are not going after expansion based on the margin as some of our competitors do.

And in terms of the AI transformation, the effects will come both from revenues and costs. I think you know that AI usually is very interesting to give the client personalized offer and to recommend the product which will be the best in his situation because we did the modeling based on the segmentation on what we know about the client that, at this particular moment, he would be more inclined of buying this or that and suggesting it to him. So that's why here, for example, one of the figures that we were looking yesterday, it's not here today, but as I said, 25% of what we offer now to the client is personalized, and it's tailored to this client need. So it definitely increases the probability of him buying this product. So this is the revenue side.

On the cost side, chatbots, for example, are wonderful. 40% of our incoming queries are now done by chatbot, so definitely decreases the number of people we need in the call centers, for example.

And Alexander, I don't know, do you want to add anything on AI? Or you will be saying something during...

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN, FIRST DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF EXECUTIVE BOARD, SENIOR VP & HEAD OF THE RISK MANAGEMENT SERVICE, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: I will address that.

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: You will address?

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: Yes.

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: Okay.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Thank you very much. We have some time for the last question. Mikhail, please? Not using the microphone. And you can switch to Russian.

MIKHAIL SHLEMOV, EQUITIESÂ ANALYST, VTB CAPITAL, RESEARCH DIVISION: [Interpreted] It's Mikhail Shlemov from VTB Capital. Yulia, when you talked about sort of the personnel, the headcount and the challenges for 2020, you mentioned that you have to address this large headcount issue because there will be a lot of employees in the ecosystem that are not typical for the bank like couriers, drivers and so on and so forth. But if you look at our -- at your operational model in terms of how you work in the ecosystem, it is based on GVs. So there is no consolidated financial reporting for the partners. Does that mean that next year, you're going to review your model of working with other partners, and you will become the managing partner there? What -- how it will impact the financial results?

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: [Interpreted] That does not mean that. We're just trying to be proactive. And even if we are not a majority shareholder, we understand that when a company has a lot of taxi drivers and couriers, that means that it affects the cost efficiency and satisfaction, and it might be a potential for us in terms of the strategic partnership with these people. But I think that you will know more about that in our new strategy.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: Yulia, thank you very much for coming here and for your presentation and for the Q&A. I think in a year, we're going to have a larger event when we're going to report on the results on all of implementation of 2020 Strategy and when we are going to present to you our new strategy. Thank you very much.

Yes, thank you all, and we're giving the floor to Alexander Vedyakhin, First Deputy Chairman of the Executive Board.

<Presentation

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: [Interpreted] Good morning, dear colleagues. It's a great pleasure to see you all here. Thank you for coming. And as far as I understand, we have people present here. The event is broadcasted. So good morning to all.

I'm going to talk about the business, the financial business -- core business of the bank that currently generates the bulk of the profits and that is paying the dividends. I'll be followed by Anatoly Popov and Natalya Alymova. Anatoly is responsible for corporate business, Natalya is responsible for the wealth management business. So you can ask questions related to these 2 businesses to me or to these 2 colleagues of mine.

Now I'm going to talk about the retail. We have some things to tell about the retail. There were some new developments. So I'm going to talk about the retail business, CIB and wealth management. So these are the 3 colleagues responsible for these businesses: Svetlana, responsible for retail business; Anatoly, CIB; and Natalya Alymova, wealth management.

We have more than 95 million retail clients, more than 2.5 million corporate clients. We deliver more than 20% ROE. Net fees and commission year-on-year are growing basically by 10%. And the net profit is RUB 633 billion. These are the profits delivered by this block.

You hear things about the retail, what's the picture? The mortgage market share is 54%. Retail loans market share, that's around 41%. And retail deposits market share is around 44%. This is a very promising figure. That means that basically every citizen of Russia, regardless of age, has a debit card issued by Sberbank. Maybe people will have even 2 debit cards, regardless of the age. But anyway, that means that we are the largest issuer of cards in Russia.

Talking about the dynamics now. It's very important that this year, we have been developing quite actively our online and distant remote channels. You see that the share of transactions went from 37% to 43%, and that's a trend. That's not it. And those who have our Sberbank Online app can select loans, interest rate, fine-tune all the parameters, just to play with it. When we launched the service, we had around 120 attempts from 1 person who was trying to get just the loan that he wanted. He was playing with all the parameters of the loan. So you can do that, too, just for fun.

Now transports acquiring, the cities with transport acquiring. This year, there will be 100 cities with transport acquiring. You can pay for your commute with your card. And the transport is equipped with the terminals so that you can pay noncash. Cash-out is our initiative that we have developed this year. And in the end of last year, it used to be 0. Now this year, it's going to be around 3,000. That's a very important thing because the availability of financial services for the population is on top of the agenda every time. And this approach helps to optimize our costs related to the opening of the new branches because opening a new branch, that's very expensive. But if you do a cash-out and pay a small fee to shop, that's okay, and that delivers -- and that caters to the needs of the customers. So we are going to develop this one, too.

Digital cards means Sberbank Online. Without going to the brick-and-mortar branch, you can get a card. And our customers have more than 1 million digital cards that you can use to pay in the Internet. Or if you have a phone with NFC, you can use this card, too. You don't need to wallet now because everything is going to be in your smartphone.

Our -- one of our favorite services that is doing great, DomClick. This slide describes its success story, RUB 4 trillion of mortgage portfolio and RUB 5 billion of annual income from new services that are delivered by DomClick. We started to develop DomClick as a mortgage platform, online platform. But now DomClick is used for the customers and by the customers to rent a flat, to buy a flat, obviously. I mean anything related to the properties, notary offices, notary services, renovation services, that's in the full -- real estate ecosystem, and we're going to develop that, and we're going to drive up the profits for this system. And as you can see, it is off to a strong story.

Product lending, POS lending, we have launched this product. Currently, it's around RUB 300 million. It's not a lot. That means lending in the point of sales. By the end of the year, we're going to double this volume, and this is one of the emerging trends in our bank. This is something we are going to actively develop with our partners. And we are now actively developing our sales network. And that means that we are going to deliver a good margin here, too.

Zero fields for our loan applications. It used to be 15% of loans, now it's 50%. We want to move this figure to 80% or 90%. That means that every person using Sberbank Online would be able to get a loan just by pushing a button, no documents, no certificates needed. So this is a very important trend. We are going to develop it even further. But now 50% of the loan applications are delivered online. And this -- when we had our own Black Friday, which is called the Green Day, Green Day of Sberbank, hundreds of thousands of requests were approved in 1 day. These were hundreds of thousands of applications for loans, and it was all delivered, thanks to the zero field technology. RUB 7.6 trillion for retail lending, that is growing from RUB 6.4 trillion. And deposits went up from RUB 12.6 trillion to RUB 13.7 trillion.

AI, Yulia has started to talk about that. Colleagues, I would like to say that AI is not some fancy tool for us. We analyze cost-to-income ratio for each initiative. We validate the profitability of each initiative. And each AI initiative, large AI initiative is verified and validated by our Department of Finance. And many of you know Mr. Morozov. And you can be quite sure that he would never -- no AI initiative would pass through him if it is not efficient enough. So we do not make these tools just to make these tools, these toys, really. We do some things that do deliver.

For instance, we have implemented -- in mass personalization, we have implemented some new things. In Sberbank Online, you have your own personalized screen. So if you compare my screen with Yulia's screen or with Morozov's screen, it will be different. The recommendations would be different. It's not only about the money and the portfolio of the instruments that we have with the recommendations. Personalized recommendations will be different. And these personalized recommendations help to boost the loyalty of the customers and to improve the consumer and other services.

In the call center, the contact center, the bulk serves about 40% of calls and chat contacts. Just for you to understand, that's a huge cost saving.

On the corporate business and the wealth management, I'm just going to breeze through a bit quicker because my colleagues are going to address those topics in greater detail. And since I've got about 10 minutes left, I'll probably leave more for handling your questions. Here's the figures, the deltas. There's a growth in the main areas, active corporate clients, the number of users and the number of users in the online channels. This thing is interesting, the 7 minutes. It used to be 1 billion. Now it's 101 billion worth of these loans. That's when corporate customer can borrow in 7 minutes, in line with -- in light of all the procedures, legal, security, underwriters, lending people and all the other businesses in the bank involved. The customer can actually get the loan in 7 minutes, dead. This is the time to money. And this portfolio is 101 billion strong, and there's a 1 and a 0 NPL.

The corporate credit portfolio has been shrinking. It has not been shrinking. That was the question. It has not been shrinking. It was rationalized. As Yulia justly said, we are maximizing our margins. Every call that we have with our analysts is, "Hello, how are you doing on margin?" This is the question number one. Number two and number three is does it maintain the right balance between the assets, liabilities and the margin. Well, some loans fall out. The lower part just drifted away, the lower income part of the portfolio. But look at the graphs in retail. This is how we maintain the overall margin bank-wide and how we -- this is how we drive this margin. And we went into marginal management to maintain that margin, and it has been stable. It is being stable now.

Wealth management, you see the figures, growth across the board. Natalya Alymova is going to dwell in detail on our successes.

Now on the approach to customers, this is a story where we launched. Conversion increased about 25%. And we are now giving personalized offers to everyone. That's what we did with Andrey Kurpatov, the Neurosciences Lab. And Andrey told us a lot of good things about communicating the right way with various types of people. Some people are more emotional, some more figure minded. Well, you are obviously more about numbers, but then there are a lot of people who are mostly about emotions and all kinds of things in between. And depending on the cytotype of the person, communication is tailored.

There's a new format -- there are new formats for distribution and working with the ecosystem. Again, Lev is going to do well in detail on that. But we are seeing a very simple story here. There are -- the banking products are increasingly commoditized, and this has been a trend for a while. For customers to get all the possible products in the bank, it would be the -- it would be highly useful to add ecosystem products to the offering. This is how we maintain the touch points for the customers. Okko is a great online streaming service, but bank customers buy into Okko. They certainly have the time to chat with our branch manager, who has the time to sell some banking services to that customer. And they are, at this time, much more profitable. This is the ecosystem that maintains the attention of the customer. So our job right now is to be as -- to spend as much time with the customer as possible both online and offline. And the changes to our branches are predicated mostly on that strategy. We will be trying a lot of new formats. You all will have heard about this McDonald's format, the [Coffee Office 2020], the new initiative about the agent network. We're going to try all kinds of formats of communicating with customers. It is important for us to maintain as short a distance with customer as possible and to meet -- satisfy as many of customer needs as we possibly can.

Self-service terminals, ATMs, they're all new. Next year, you're going to see newer ATMs still, new, bigger screen ATMs, AI-driven ATMs that can personalize the offering to any specific individual that approaches the ATM. There's going to be biometrics there. But the outcomes, you're going to see those next year. We're going to dwell on those next year again.

Sales agents, 3,500 that has been developing and it will develop even further. What our colleagues in the branch network are doing is selling. They are being assisted with next-best-thing prompts. And because this is pretty tedious, when all those prompts pop up, just go ahead and just do this. This customer needs to be sold this and that, this, this is the machine, obviously, and this is part of the engines of our efficiency, but this is pretty difficult. I mean psychologically, it's difficult. So we developed a kind [e-sonic ISU]. This is a smart management system of Sberbank that gives the proposals, and you can talk, you can chat with this kitten-like character. It helps to drive the sales. 128 dialogues have been recorded with [e-sonic] with this pet character.

We have this gamification lab. Our offices facing customers are doing a lot of hard work. So this helps to lower the psychological tension on the part of those customer-facing staff. And 59% MAU is again very cool.

The Teal branches, these are the branches with a lot of initiatives delegated to the employees as opposed to managers. Twice is -- the engagement is twice higher. We don't really push them. This is a very interesting format. We have been using it very actively. And gamification is, again, a major track of activity advanced at the bank.

Regional projects, a big topic. PPP, public private partnerships, we have been advancing that actively. Anatoly Popov is going to give you more flesh on that.

AI transformation, I'm going to skip certain slides. Now this is what we have been speaking about, what Yulia brought up. Again, in 2020, AI transformation is going to give us Sberbank the additional $1 billion in income, an additional $1 billion in income. That's just one figure to illustrate the efficiency, AI transformation of Sberbank, 2020, the additional $1 billion income. These are -- this is a verified figure. The finance department verified that. This is not an arbitrary off the top of my head figure. We have a very rigorous procedure around these figures driven by the finance department. AI transformation is a major effort inside the bank to drive efficiency.

Very importantly, the processes, whenever we introduce AI into any process, AI works like a magic sauce. It cuts costs. It increases customer loyalty, internal and external. And AI can transform processes beyond recognition. The 7-minutes process, the lending in 7 minutes, we just put aside the underwriters and lending people for a while, and we introduced the people who are savvy in machine learning. They drew up the 7-minute process. Then we verified it, then we honed it and polished it, but AI can change that process top to bottom. This is a new generation of processes.

And the management of processes is another priority. It's another major initiative. In the bank, the whole Executive Board is behind it, and it has been developing very actively.

Perhaps so much I can say on this. I've got 1.4 minutes. But if colleagues give me more time, I can handle more questions. Yes, let's play it by ear. Let's start with those questions. Yes.

MIKHAIL GANELIN, SENIOR ANALYST OF FINANCE, INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY, TRANSPORT, ATON LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: [Interpreted] Mikhail Ganelin, Aton. We appreciate there's more room to boost efficiency through AI of all things. Product sales, you speak a lot about that. More products are going to be offered by live streaming services. Do you think the capacity is there? You are selling an X number of products to a customer. Going forward 3 to 5 years, can you increase that products per customer number? And the simple part of the question, POS lending, Sberbank used to be in it. You quit it for a while, and now you are back in it. What are the plans here?

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: [Interpreted] Thank you, Mikhail. As I'm answering your first question, we are using this sales shelf in our work, this concept of sales shelf. All the touch points, they're essentially marks, they're essentially window -- shop windows. People obviously have some kind of limitation on buying, psychological, financial, temporal. There's all kinds of limitations. Now we created a financial model that allows us to rationalize sales with -- from the same shelf. I mean some products are on the same shelf. But in terms of retail, some products are just facing customers on the eye level. This is the first contact that is done by our customer relationship manager. These are mostly, obviously -- this is obviously the most profitable products. But if the customer have a special need or has the time or wish, we have a dynamic sales shelf that provides this next best section, next best offer. And it suggests the next thing to offer to this customer. This is obviously smart management system-based, and it rationalizes the sale while obviously maximizing the profit and customer lifetime value for each individual customer. But this should not be pushy because, otherwise, we're going to be pushing all the high-margin products on people, forcing people off with it without building that balance. But I think right now, we are building that balance.

This concept of sales shelf, dynamic sales shelf, that allows us to rationalize the sales, profit and maintain the length of customer relationship because you can burn out a customer, just pile on the products on them, borrow that mortgage, get some life insurance from us, the accrual type, and preferably use something more profitable from us and bolt on some kind of a derivative on that consumer loan. And the customer might be very, very disappointed in 6 months.

So our objective is to maximize not just NPV but customer lifetime value, CLTV.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Mikhail Shlemov and then another lady. I can't fail to reject that. And Mikhail Shlemov always asks the right -- the interesting questions. Thank you.

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: [Interpreted] I do not think this is the right thing to do, and this is not vindicated -- I mean the decrease of the branch network, this is not vindicated by any calculations. The branch network is our powerful advantage at this time. No one has a branch network like ours. I mean there's a bank that is close to us in scale but not the quality and not the depth of penetration. No one has that. And the bundling this strategic advantage would be shortsighted. It would not be farsighted.

We -- I mean another question is how we use that strategic advantage the right way, but this is a strategic advantage, make no mistake about it. And even the branches and remote areas are an advantage of the same kind. We have been following this active sales shelf concept, all other -- all kinds of other strategies. We need to use all those to turn the branch into a touch point, into a gravity point that would be self-recouping in terms of cost-to-income ratio. This is not easy. This is what we have been laboring hard on with our finance people, but this is what we see to be our advising, continuing strategic advantage. We have the slogan, make [VSPs], make branches great again.

MIKHAIL SHLEMOV: [Interpreted] Alexander, very interesting presentation. When you spoke about AI, you mentioned that the finance department clears all the initiatives. And how do you assess the financial efficiency of bundling ecosystem products? What is this going to mean in terms of customer returns or in maximization of customer lifetime value or NPV? How do you assess that effect?

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: [Interpreted] That's a good question, Mikhail. Thank you. We evaluate that from several standpoints. First off, we measure the CLTV, customer lifetime value, because if we start measuring ecosystem products in NPV terms or next year's profit, you won't see a lot of immediate financial outcome. But having said that, we are selling services that are frequently used, and they are for the long term. Mobile service, mobile connectivity, a frequently used long-term service; video streaming, frequently used long-term service. So we are trying to develop this custom on the part of clients, remember Sberbank much more frequently than they have the need for financial services because right now, most loans -- I mean already, most of the loans are in people's pockets. It used to be a whole big story. I mean it used to take 2 weeks to take out a cash loan. Now it takes about 3 minutes. And if it's 5 minutes, people stop borrowing. What is this about? Why are we not getting the approval in 2 minutes? So that's becoming increasingly commoditized. But a person does not need a loan every day, thankfully. They need mortgage like 2 times, lifetime deposits, not really payments, well, you put auto payments. So we need high-frequency, long-term services that we are going to use to build the good relations with the customers. And sometimes, we subsidize -- kind of subsidize some of these areas, some of these business lines, but we get the attention of the customers. And we are going to be the first choice when a customer needs our high-profit, high-yield financial service.

So yes, we target CLTV for bundles. We have NPV and CLTV evaluations that are run differently because we might have a great CLTV but then the NPV would be negative. So this is a kind of combination of factors. But Morozov is always making this a hard time for us. Literally, I love the questions, by the way.

ANDREY MIKHAILOV, RESEARCH ANALYST, SOVA CAPITAL LIMITED, RESEARCH DIVISION: [Interpreted] Andrey Mikhailov, Sova Capital. I would like to go back to the $1 billion of effects of the AI. And the question is in what segments do you see the most -- the major effect and perhaps some products that were the most affected by the AI transformation.

ALEXANDER A. VEDYAKHIN: [Interpreted] Thank you very much for your question. It's very simple. The more standardized transactions there are, the more AI is used. First of all, this is a retail business where you have this kind of massive story about massive standard transactions. Corporate business, they need to make quick decisions, and the actions are massive and standardized and typical. Compliance, it is a very complicated checks that is done in compliance, yet the machine intelligence does help to address these complicated compliance issues. And obviously all of our internal processes and decisions, we used to take experts to make a decision or we built some very complicated algorithms. Now AI helps us to understand what to improve in specific processes within the bank, in our back office and basically in all of our service and functions.

So basically, I think there is no large process in the bank that would not be AI-driven. But first of all, the top priority is massive typical transactions, the way we use AI. And we use AI as a magic sauce, and it's kind of improves the efficiency like by 20% or 30%. It delivers $1 billion like let's just use it everywhere.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Okay. Thank you very much, colleagues, for the questions. Thank you very much, Mr. Vedyakhin. And Anatoly Popov is the next speaker. Thank you.

ANATOLY POPOV, DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF EXECUTIVE BOARD, SENIOR VP & HEAD OF THE CORPORATE BUSINESS BLOCK, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted] Good morning, dear friends. It's a great pleasure for me to see you all here.

When I go and talk about the corporate business and about the global markets, I think we will start with the most important things. The client base growth in the small business, it is the client base that is the generator of the profits. If you take a look at the profitable segments, the most profitable segment in the corporate lending is small business in Sberbank. So small business issues are on top of the agenda -- of our agenda. These figures that you see in terms of the customer base growth, these are good. And our bank has become the best bank or the first choice bank for the small business, a very quick very profitable bank, very affordable bank. Our fees are very attractive, and it helps to get our customers to acquiring and selling their products. These are the most profit-generating products.

And if you talk about the yields and profitability in small businesses, small businesses -- for small businesses, I mean the bank has a huge operational income and fee and commission income. And this fee income is larger than compared with the largest segment.

If you talk about the dynamics for the corporate loan portfolio, it's quite -- it's going quite okay. We do not -- we were not very aggressive here. We're not very aggressive to grow the market share. But the quality of loan portfolio and the margin is the most important things because, obviously, if we give out high-quality loans, that means that the margin is growing and our quality is higher than compared with the competitors. We like complicated and challenging projects. We do not like this routine lending stuff. We want to participate in projects with upside and just to have some challenge. But that means that our loan portfolio growth is quite -- might look quite tepid.

The appreciation of the Russian ruble also means that the growth of the portfolio was not that high. But if you look at the segments of small business and medium businesses, they are the most -- they deliver the most -- the majority of the margin, and they are growing as quickly -- quicker than everyone else. And that means that we deliver the loans that are very profitable for us.

And another thing, perhaps the currency breakdown, ruble and dollar. In 2016 and 2015, 2014, after the crisis, there was quite a lot of corporate loans denominated in foreign currency, but we have committed ourselves to implement the following rule. If a customer has a foreign-denominated revenue, they can get a foreign-denominated -- foreign currency-dominated loan. So if they're exporting something, that's okay. Obviously, there's -- for development, for instance, we do not give the developers dollar-denominated loans. So we focus and prioritize these foreign-denominated -- foreign currency-denominated loans to the exporters and other companies.

Market shares, everything is stable in small business and the large business. Talking about the deposits we're working better here. In terms of the corporate deposits, we now are able to quote the deposits in online for all customers in 1 second. And for largest companies that have short-term deposits and long-term deposits with us, and that goes for the small and medium businesses, all these tools are available online. That means that we can grow our market share in the corporate deposit market.

Now small business lending, this is SME lending, there is a registry of these companies done by the tax authority. We see that we are growing market shares 35.3% from 1.1 trillion to 1.7 trillion, we're growing. That's our growth. Without that, the SME lending would stagnate in Russia, and that means that Sberbank is driving all that market, SME lending market. And this year, we are continuing the stable growth. It was 17% of annual growth. Last year, it was 20%. That means that we are the leading bank in this market. And we are better than all the banks combined in this market.

If you're talking about the state support mechanisms Sberbank is using quite actively, we are leading in all programs, in all state programs of the subsidies. This is the program of the Ministry of Agriculture that subsidize the key rate. And in line with this program, this kind of small farms have a 20% of support and 80% program of the Ministry of Economic Development. And we got RUB 140 billion there from this program, benefited from this program. And we have a very positive outlook for the next year. And the Far Eastern Development Program, this is the program for support of the small towns, in all these programs, Sberbank is a leading player. And 20% of our SME portfolio was formed, thanks to using this or that state support mechanism. So 80% are -- in 80% of the cases, we're using the tools that we have created ourselves.

Now there were some questions about the ecosystems. I will try to talk about the ecosystem. Any business starts with opening a company, with starting the company. Sberbank delivered a unique tool. There are no similar tools around the world. It helps a customer, a physical person of Sberbank. They can register a business or a sole trader, to become a sole trader from the comfort of their sofa. And this is a very friendly tool that was created together with the government of the Russian Federation. You can use the electronic signature on your smartphone.

How it works? You take your smartphone with an NFC reader. And after working with 2 years, after negotiating 2 years with the Apple Corporation, it is now available on Apple smartphones. It used to be on the Android software. So you put your NFC scanner to your foreign passport, and the electronic signature is generated. So you can start a company, and you can open a settlement account at Sberbank.

Now if you look at the right-hand side of the slide, 80% of the companies are -- 8% of the companies are registering through Sberbank, and it is growing. All -- many -- the majority of companies use our personal profile. And from this 8%, the conversion to the settlement accounts is 80%. So that means that if you look at the figures, like in 2016, from 100,000 because, well, every month in Russia, around 90,000 companies are registering business -- their business. And now -- and 60% of them now select Sberbank to open a settlement account, that we have affordable products, good bundles with effective tools. The registration experience is very seamless. So you don't need to go to the tax authority or the branch. It takes less than 3 days. And obviously, the most important thing is that 52% select Sberbank as the only bank for settlement. So they have no other settlement accounts in any other bank.

That means that it helps to ensure effective settlements because the settlements between the customers of Sberbank, 80% of the payments are done in 1 minute. And we have a new type of requests from our customers. When customers want to revoke the payments and the payment has been already delivered, and we are working to make sure that the payments between companies could be done in 1 second with all KYC procedures and anti-fraud procedures implemented. So instant payments, it's a very near future including for the companies.

Going to loans now. You perhaps were quite surprised in terms of the figures of the loan portfolio growth, and it is driven by the digital tools, first of all. Now first of all, the first major tool is RUB 10 million loan in 3 minutes. 1.3 million customers have preapproved credit limits, so they can benefit from this feature. So that's a large corporation.

You asked about AI technologies. These are AI technologies. These are the limits where we -- that we use that would calculate using the working capital, using the salaries information, using the settlement account information and transaction information. And we can use all this data to forecast the credit worthiness and preapprove a limit for a loan. And you can apply for a loan in 3 minutes. So you can see that the number of transactions is growing, and it's huge. And it helps us in 3 minutes to give these loans in the system that is called Sberbank Business Online.

Another large segment, there is a new segment, this is a self-employed segment. Last year, Russia started experiments in 4 regions of Russia. And now a physical person can register himself or herself as a self-employed person in the federal tax service. Now if you're self-employed, you are delivering services to the physical as persons. If you sell hats in Instagram, you can register yourself as self-employed. You can get -- send an invoice, and you will have a proper relations with your customers. And you pay only 4% of the customer. If you like, for instance, clean the windows for a company, a company can pay to you legally and you will pay only 6% of the taxes. And you can register as self-employed, and you can service your tax and you can receive all the needed information and generate the invoices in Sberbank Business Online system. This service has been -- was launched in March this year, and we have more than 200,000 self-employed using this solution. In 2020, we are planning the rollout of the solution to 19 regions. And I think that, very soon, all regions will benefit from this solution. And the potential for this segment, it's 15 million customers that can be employed legally and benefit, the tools delivered by Sberbank. And that will mean that they can do legal business. And the companies can have legal relations, proper relations with the contractors.

Now corporate cards. The corporate cards segment in Russia is, well, not that developed. And if you look at the American markets to compare it with, the business cards are used for the state paid -- payments and other things. Russia has a great potential for development. We have 40% of the market share, and we have tens of millions of people working in companies. Obviously, every employee of a company must have a corporate card perhaps not in the physical form, not in the plastic form but in their smartphone to pay for some things that the company needs. That goes for online payments, for some expenses, travel expenses and anything you can buy to work in the company. We can start with a debit card. We have credit card and travel card. The Banker awarded us as the best business in -- as the best banking business cards in CEE region. And you can see that, this year, the growth -- the income from business cards is RUB 17 billion. It used to be RUB 10 billion in 2017. So I'd like to thank our CFO for that effort -- who gave me coffee. That's the most expensive coffee I got, I guess in my life. Anyway, we see that the -- this business card line is off to a strong story. And I think that very soon we are going to have a profit of more than 50 billion in this segment.

Now talking about the medium and large segment and these AI-powered loans in 7 minutes. We talked about 3 minutes for loans up to RUB 10 million, and now you can have a loan up to RUB 2 billion in 7 minutes. That's the reality. It's working. When we talk about 7 minutes, the loans that we deliver, well, I mean there was this security and other things there. The legal structure is more difficult. And our robots, our AI solutions can analyze it all, can conclude, can contract and sign in electronic form these contracts. We have more than 100,000 limits approved for the companies. And it can only be signed in Sberbank Business Online.

Now going to the change of federal law at -- 214, finance in the residential construction with escrow. Sberbank delivered 7.6 -- 76% of the financing. This is a very high-margin finance. It's very efficient financing because we selected the best borrowers in the market. We were the first ones to give the first loan to the first ones to open the escrow accounts. And obviously, we are a -- the key player on this market. This year, our portfolio doubled in terms of the finance of the residential construction.

Agriculture is one of the quickest industries -- one of the quickest-growing industries in Russian Federation, and Sberbank is a leading institution that finances the industry. 35% of financing to agro is coming from Sberbank. We are supporting exporters through our trading arm in SberbankSwitzerland because every second ship that travels through Bosphorus with grain was financed by Sberbank. We actively work in that market, and we see great potential in that market.

In every tech presentation, there's generally a horrible slide. This is my version of it. This actually is the architectural diagram of an insignificant part of our architecture, probably from 9 years ago. Just imagine, if this can be -- if this is to be expanded, it is pretty impossible to live in such an architecture. It might be interesting but not productive from all the viewpoints. We pretty often use -- in public presentations, we pretty often use a slide. We call it, lovingly, the pie, the layered cake. You can see the channels, the products. I'm not going to dwell on that. That's when you leave an organization with a lot of engineers and developers, it is logical to understand how productive they are. One historic perspective to share. You have been hearing about the platform for a long time, one way or another. So we see the story of our platform, the story of our tech transformation in 3 phases. In the run-up to 2017, we went through a complex and revolutionary transformation that was about centralization. Thousands of systems we got centralized. In 2018, the new platform -- we started developing the platform earlier, but in 2018, there was a big breakthrough in the platform, we launched our private cloud. And most of our applications became cloud-ready. And as I told you, we have started investing into unified development environment that was called SberWorks. In 2019, the basic platform elements were all launched as an industrial operation. And the platform became not just a reality, it became a dependence. It became the core foundation of our business plans and operating success. And until 2020, we intend to transition 80% of customer transactions into the platform.

I drew your attention to one of the elements of the platform, SberWorks. Now I'd like to highlight the 2 other as important elements. That's what we are already operating on an industrial basis. That's UFS or unified front-end system. I'm not going to read the slides. We take great pride in what we have built. This is a cloud-native multichannel architecture. It is in production. Hopefully, you use Sberbank one way or another. And you are already, if you are using Sberbank, you already are using one of these. And 8 products, the first 8 products, some of them completely new, are already on that platform, and they are operated on an industrial basis.

Let me tell you why this outcome is important. It's not technology for the sake of technology that we invested in. We write much less code, that's important, 50% less on average than the old paradigm equivalent. And probably, the time to market is the most important metric. We always measure our success not in terms of, "We had an idea and we implemented it." We measure the time to implementation. It might be an existing product or a new product. It was about how soon can we take it to the customers. We see 7x improvement on average. Sometimes it's 8x to 10x in some products.

As I've said, we have a very large tech team. The most recent statistic is, I think about 19 -- oh, it was about 1,900 squads without overlapping. They are developing in parallel on the platform. Why did we start building it? Because we were able to deploy a lot of products into industrial deployment and do that -- and that was possible in parallel.

Historically, and this is still a very frequent occurrence in the market, not just in banking, people generally plan capacity using this approach. They use the utilization of the product. They appreciate that there will be some peaks or some generated holidays, and they buy capacity licenses for that peak. Now what happens when that peak is not there? In our old paradigm, nothing used to happen. The equipment was there. It cooled -- it warmed the air, it cooled the air. But that was a good model for operating in like 1985. We don't work like this anymore. So we aggressively pushed into cloud, and we take great pride in what we accomplished. In November, 80% of all the capacity in Sberbank was granted in our private cloud. That is materially improving our utilization. Utilization has grown about 4x, not 4%, 4x. And then from the perspective of the internal customer, if the customer needs capacity, we give it in minutes and not in months as it used to be. This is not planned. This is happening. This is reality. This is our new reality.

Here's another element. We've kind of strewn the history of our platform development across multiple slides. A very interesting integration element. It's called Synapse. That is our corporate bus. I don't know what the Russian version is. That's the modern ESB, enterprise service bus. Our architectural solutions are increasingly drifting towards micro services. Communications between micro services are increasingly more important for the final product. We built our own solution. And the latency of this platform is 50x better than the commercial solutions that we used to operate.

The fundamental topic for us, we are working in the paradigm of best of both worlds. We are not willing to abandon the R&D dollars that the Western companies invest into their products. Yet we do not want to be fully dependent on, I don't know, sanctions or product development pursued by other companies. We selectively use either one or the other. And very often, we have a choice inside our platform, open source solutions or proprietary solutions, commercial solutions. Achieving that is difficult because generally, when an architectural decision is made, you are taking either one path or the other. We decided that we are going to be doing it slightly differently just because we want to maximize R&D -- the use of R&D dollars spent in the world.

I told you about SberWorks. That is our cycle. It was drawn linearly from idea to testing, deployment and plugging into the operations and then monitoring, but this is obviously a cycle. I just wanted to tell you how we measure the success of our development cycle. But first off, everything that we write is available for reuse, 100%. There's not a component that would be developed by 1 squad of the 2,000 out there that another squad would not be able to use, reuse. And we measure the DSI or CSI of our developers. It's important because there's fight for talent worldwide, especially in the Russian market. The good engineer has a choice of where to continue his career. We want to -- we want them to want to stay in Sberbank. One of the meaningful reasons why they want to stay is that we give them a very productive, easy-to-use and developing development tool. Mr. Gref keeps saying that 84% is not 100%, but this is pretty, pretty high as an indicator. And we take, again, pride in that.

Let me tell you a little bit about the data. When I started working in Sberbank about 2 years ago -- again, this is a pretty standard story, but I'm going to share it nonetheless, we used to have these data scientists. We still have them. Pretty much any big organization has them. And I asked them, "When you come to work, what exactly do you do? What percentage of your time do you pursue your core activity like analysis models, et cetera?" And they said, "When we have a lot of data, that's okay. We do something. We don't do much when the data is raw or we lack data." So we decided to address this problem. Address them in what way? When you entered, dear colleagues, you saw the light that was on. Has anyone asked the question, how did we get the electricity there? What was used, the heat power plant, nuclear power plant to put this lighting on? No. We come to work. We come home. There is a switcher. The light is on when you switch it. We want to have the same with data because data is our electricity. You cannot find electricity when you come to work. You need to do what you are paid for. And what we call data factory, it is our internal in-house power plant that does very challenging and complicated things related to data and that make data available and useful. In the fourth quarter, we were able to get 4 hours to get the subscription for data. An analyst has an idea. He wants to test some hypothesis to develop a model. He needs data, and he gets the data in around 2 hours irregardless of the volume of the data required.

Cloud-native. When I talked about the platform, and in 2018, I said that the majority of our applications are cloud-ready, and that is so. But cloud-ready is kind of an intermediary step in our journey to become cloud-native. I wanted to explain to you why is that important. For instance, you -- imagine you have a team. 10,000 people. All are very talented engineers. You pay them huge salaries, and they go to work and make decisions. They make decisions on how to scale, how to monitor, how to implement scalability. It's not important whether the decisions are wrong or not. Maybe they would be wrong. Maybe all of them would be wrong. But since it is 10,000 of them, it kind of -- you kind of have analogy to anarchy. And cloud-native, why we have underlined the word auto here, automatic. We want the cloud to make this decision automatically once and for all and the engineers not to make all the decisions every day. They should concentrate on the business logic and other things. And why is that important for us? Because availability and monitoring and scalability are great -- are things that we do great. But we want to do it once, to make the decisions related to these things once. So cloud-native, for us, is a target architecture structure and strategy irregardless of the domain we're working them out -- we're working in.

AI cloud and Kristofari. I think many of you have heard that we have launched the most powerful supercomputer in Russia. It is the 29th supercomputer in the world. We were not trying to position ourselves to be like on the 29th place or 31st place. That was not important. But if you have resolved the problem with data, you have to make some applications on that. And our resolution of the problem with the data was, for us, to most efficiently use the AI algorithms. So data, that's important. And compute, that's the second pillar. We need a lot of compute. And Kristofari is our main ingredient in this journey. This is some background information. We took one standard model that we developed for ourselves, what is in the following mode. We built our own infrastructure, and we taught the model -- trained the model in 2 weeks. We can use some popular cloud provider, Russian providers or international providers, so that's going to be 1 day to train a model. And for Kristofari, you see it's even lower than that. It dramatically changes the time to train the model.

Now I'm going to the end of my presentation. I would say there is no plan B. There is no plan B that -- like there is a digital platform and plan B with some other platform. No. All our business plans across the bank and across the ecosystem as well are based on 1 state-of-the-art and thought-through digital platform. And it would be quite strange for us to use this product only for ourselves and to offer to the market some other things. No. Obviously, that is not so. We suggest -- we offer to the market the same platform that we use ourselves. So you come to my family, I would give you the same food that I give to my family. The same situation is here. For the bank, for the members of the ecosystem, for our customers, for our partners, it is going to be one platform.

And this like Sber means that this is the best product in Russia and perhaps in the world. And we are very proud of that. So thank you very much.
