ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] And we are welcoming our next speaker, Lev Khasis, First Deputy Chairman of the Board. He's going to open a session of presentations about the ecosystem of Sberbank.

KHASIS LEV ARONOVICH, FIRST DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD & COO, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted] Good afternoon, dear colleagues, ladies and gentlemen. It is my great pleasure to welcome you here and to share with you our developments in the ecosystem. And I'll be happy to answer your questions. So I will start.

We think that many years ago, when Gref became -- began starting to use the word business ecosystem, it was a totally new notion in Russia. No one knew what it was. Russia is no exception, you know. The term ecosystem appeared several years, several decades ago, but for many years, it was only used by researchers and economists. And only recently, the interest of this notion and term has been growing. If you now go to Google and enter "business ecosystem" in the search pane, you will find 150 million articles and discussions that discuss this issue. There are several concepts and visions. Dozens of thousands of companies around the world announced that they were building an ecosystem. And Russia is no exception. This hype can be felt in Russia, too. Yet there is a difference, a small difference in the overwhelming majority of the countries. They were not able to build their own ecosystems because they were invaded by the ecosystems that came from China or the U.S. For instance, in Europe, I really cannot remember one European-based ecosystem. So that market is dominated by American ecosystem.

So if you talk about Russia, this is kind of a house race of the ecosystems has only started. These are just some companies that either publicly announced that they are building an ecosystem, or perhaps they have not announced that, but de facto, you can see some new elements of the ecosystem that are being built by them. I put them in alphabetic order. And it is really hard to understand who is going to be more successful or less successful, but we can see that after -- like yesterday and the day before yesterday, we saw 2 -- our competing banks announce about the creation of their super apps. There was a hot debate started, like who is the first one. After that, Yandex and Mail. Ru came out saying, "What exactly are you talking about? We have had super apps for a long while now." I think this dialogue is meaningless because Facebook wasn't the first social network, nor was Instagram, and the outcome of this competition is probably too early to sum up. I think we should do that in a couple of years.

Let's talk about the philosophy that underpins that. Any big organization will probably have a certain set of advantages, strong suits, targets, and it has its own logic, its own philosophy, its own goal-setting methods in building the ecosystem. All the goals will be different. When Sberbank announced its strategy of building an ecosystem at the Investor Day in 2017, we set out in great detail what our rationale was, why we intend to do that. I'm not trying to reconstruct, reenact that presentation again here. Just to mention the key points. In light of our competitive positioning in the market and the long-term vision for our shareholders, we think we should not be defensive. We should not wait while all the applicants and pretty much everyone wishes to bite a certain piece of the turf that we are in, where we are earning money, where we are serving our customers. We want to go forward. And instead of being on the defensive, we would like to go on the offensive and find new markets and services that we would offer to our customers. That was the rationale.

We want -- we must use our strong sales. That's our brand. That's the #1 brand in Russia. And certainly, by a large margin, this is the brand trusted the most by the people more than any other brand. We need to use our tech capability, our relationship with individuals and companies alike. And at the end of the day, we need to use our branch network that, in our view, has great value. We already see that this branch network can advance us in a big way in terms of selling our nonbanking products because our experience of promoting our own banking products tells us that they began to dominate the market, became the most attractive in the market because we were able to educate our customers in using those digital products. We were able to help upload those products and use those products. So our offline network is one of the very important drivers in advancing our digital products. And naturally, all the analysts fell into 2 camps. One camp said that, "You are right in doing that." They were great supporters. The other camp said, "You are going crazy. Why exactly do you need that? Your proposition that tech giants are going to encourage in your turf is complete rubbish. No one is willing to go into the domain of the regulated business, the heavily regulated business that banking is." So I would like to thank the analysts that do understand our rationale and support us.

And here's a couple of points addressed to the other camp. Now first off, we see that big companies, big tech companies are increasingly experimenting and running pilot projects with regulated businesses, the other things that include regulated businesses. They are encroaching on this turf. Also, the regulated business, the things that are within this regulatory pail, is increasingly commoditized. Marketplaces emerge. Commercial marketplaces emerge. The initiative of the Russian Central Bank is to create this marketplace. Everyone is trying to become the intermediary between the regulated banks and their customers. So the main money is not the money within this pail of regulated turf. They are the hard money. The margins are going to fall there, and those margins are going to fall not just due to macro indicators but due to the cost of access to customers through nonbanking solutions, lifestyle solutions, service solutions. That is going to increase, but continuously. So if we think of our future, even over the midterm and hopefully over the long term, we must think about how we can earn the money, how we can serve our customers not inside this regulatory pail, but we need to go beyond into the adjacent territories.

I could say a few words about the rationale that drives us into non-banking businesses. We are not building brick factories. We are not producing sausages. We would like to establish businesses that are either aggregators or marketplaces. Those will allow us not only to not compete with our mass customers, but they will allow us to cooperate and help in developing the small and medium enterprises. We see the importance of those services for people and companies alike. We see the ability of these businesses to digitize right now and right here. Some of these businesses are telecoms. They are already digital. And further digitization is not as fast as it used to be happening 10 or 20 years ago. And when we are looking at the businesses like e-commerce and food, those markets are huge. That's what we could see. And the speed of digitization is really, really huge. And this is what sets us our priorities. But then again, this is one of the examples to illustrate our rationale. We are not trying to be exhaustive in describing the entire picture of the ecosystem that we're building with this example.

Now in our view, there's a material difference between the multi-industrial holding that owns a lot of companies across various industries and an ecosystem. We think the most important difference is in that an ecosystem creates a seamless customer experience. The ecosystem uses certain uniting technological marketing and other elements, and these elements rationalize the cost of customer acquisition. The lifetime value of relating to customers is increased in that, and this is the strength of the ecosystem. Importantly, very importantly, the ecosystem is not something built near Sberbank. Sberbank is an inherent and integral part of the ecosystem. And ecosystem is essentially our new business model that allows us to expand considerably what you would call a total addressable market. We are offering not just banking products but non-banking products as well to our customers, and not necessarily do these products have to be offered by companies that we own. We think we have a great potential to relate to pretty much the entire market in offering the best products to our customers.

Why are we sometimes buying a second of those businesses? Well, again, to create additional value for our shareholders. If you imagine our customer base and our capabilities, you can easily understand that any business that can, together with us, promote our services for our customer base, that business will, by definition, become a unicorn. And if we don't have any upside -- any equity upside, that's going to be charity, a charitable effort to enrich the shareholders of those businesses or target businesses. We have shareholders of our own, so we think about those first.

And very importantly, this approach is about partnership. We pretty much never buy 100% ownership of companies. We do have certain greenfield developments, but they are the minority. The absolute majority of our deals are the deals of partnership. And this is our philosophy: We do not wish to have a scorched earth. We wish to have a great multitude of partners that work with us. And even on the list of companies that are one way or another part of the construction ecosystem, there's a lot of companies either in a JV with us, in a joint activity with us, or we are talking about that in one way or another. Mail.ru and Alexander Mamut, that is our partner with Mamut; AFK Sistema; Yandex; even Gazprombank, we have joint businesses with; even Tinkoff, that became the first bank that got connected to our P2P transfer system. Now this shows the openness of our approach for everyone to be able to work with us. Very importantly, a lot of our subsidiaries also have the ability, just at the drop of a hat, to start relating not just with us but with other financial institutions, for instance, this very successful subsidiary of ours, Evotor. It's actively working with about 80% of the 20 largest banks in Russia. And this is wonderful because this significantly expands their ability to develop their own business.

Let me give you a summary of what we have accomplished already over the past couple of years. Despite the ecosystem's strategy having been adopted in 2017, the preconditions were in existence pretty much since 2012. And since then, we invested in 25 companies. Most of those companies were created as a greenfield. We did not buy those. We created them from scratch. You will see that in net assets, the share of funds earmarked on that is pretty much a margin of error despite being a sizable figure in absolute terms. Now please note that we only note -- only mention here non-financial companies. We have a lot of financial companies. They are not in these figures.

Now let me tell you several things about our approach to M&A. Again, there is this myth in the market. I actually tried that test. I put this question to people, "How many companies do you think Sberbank bought?" The first answer off the top of that had -- people say, in light of the overall noise, 200 companies, maybe 300. That is obviously a myth. Since 2012, the total of companies that we bought, excluding the venture investments via the venture fund, the accelerator, the total we bought -- we invested in 10 companies. And that includes financial and nonfinancial companies alike. Yandex. Money was the investment of 2012. That said, in 2019, we entered 4 new industries. That was an eventful year. Importantly, to make those 4 decisions, we had analyzed over 200 various targets, and we approached the M&A through -- with great discipline. And then in the absolute majority of ideas, we adopt a negative decision. Four out of 200, that is a good indicator, showing that we are pretty open to looking at a lot of opportunities while deciding only on the opportunities that meet all of our criteria, and you see those on your slide.

That is a lot of a difference. That sets us apart from international examples. We're not trying to chase those other benchmarks. I'd like to draw your attention that a lot of other ecosystems that is on everyone's lips, they'd buy companies by the hundreds, sometimes a company a week. And we are quite far from them. We're not trying to chase them, to be sure. I think that if you talk about large industries, we formed the perimeter that we are interested in. Yes, there might be some reorganizations and attempts to order. We might think that some businesses are not growing. We might think there's some business that aren't growing fast enough. We might sell something, and we might enter something else. But I do not think that some new -- major new industry is going to come up that I would like to enter with some huge investments to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars. And if that is under $100 million or under $150 million, those cases are possible. But in light of the scale of our activity, that is entirely possible.

We will certainly be focusing, in particular, on the projects that we already have. And that we are going to dwell on a bit later but still today. Very importantly, our M&A strategy mandates us to be a partner in a leading player right away and has a whole number of advantages. But in many cases, we are trying to enter the industry via the #2 or #3 player because we think that certain technological improvements multiplied by the capability that we are contributing will achieve us the leadership for a lot less as opposed to paying this enormous premium for the #1 leader in the market. And here are some non-leaders in the Russian market that we think might vie for the pole position over the next 2 to 3 years, maybe 5. They are here, but we'll be working actively on that.

Very importantly, and I mentioned that before, an ecosystem is only possible when all those businesses are not disjointed and disunited, but united into something: seamless customer experience; single standards of, say, cybersecurity; and many other things. For us, we identified 25, maybe 26 uniting elements of the ecosystem. In some subsidiaries, they all got introduced 100%. Some are only beginning to introduce them. But in the 2020, we are aiming to make all these ecosystem companies to use those uniting elements that will boost the growth that we are aiming for.

This is an incomplete brand list of our companies and services. A lot of names here are not matching the names of the service. Sometimes a company owns more than one brand, but then you are getting an idea from the slide of the very broad gamut of brands and other recognizable services in various domains of life of both our individual private customers and corporate customers that are, again, our clients.

Let me talk a few -- say a few words about the priorities of ours for 2020. As we think about our customers, we simply have to pay attention to the most important customer segment that are state or municipal outfits. And here, our very important priority is to enter that market. And we understand this market to be the various services for the state and municipal enterprises and the services for individuals and entities -- providing the public services to individuals and entities, services that used to be provided by the government. So we're liaising actively with all levels of government. We have a very interesting lineup for them: IT services, cloud services, what David mentioned, the IT platform. There's some back-office functions, accounting, bookkeeping, various other business administration services, cybersecurity, AI, public procurement, biometrics. All of those services we would like to actively promote among the companies that operate for the organizations that operate in this segment.

And also, we are keen to remember that the Digital Economy government program designated Sberbank as the center of competence in 2 critically important areas. That's AI and cybersecurity. We are paying particular attention to that. David mentioned the public cloud of artificial intelligence that's going to be available for the entire nation. And we are looking at this as a major financial function and a business. Now here, I would like to say a few words about our individual customers. I tried to make it as simple as possible. And the most important area of working with this customer segment can be described with these 4 things: breadth, circuses, mobility and assurance and security -- safety and security. That does not mean that there are no other areas that are important for our retail customers, but these are the pillars really.

So let's talk about this breadth. This industry is radically changing. I made an experiment once. Let's -- let me make this experiment again. We have the majority of men here. Yet there are some women, too. Ladies, could you raise a hand if you wear something that you sewed yourself? No hands risen. You sewed yourself? Are you wearing something? I think that 50 or 60 years ago, if I asked this question, there would be a lot of women who would raise their hands. That means that the clothing industry in this 50, 60 years has changed radically. And I know that -- well, I mean, obviously, there are some amateurs. But if I ask some men, do -- can you use a bow and arrows? Some men say, "Yes, I can do that. I can hunt with bow and arrows."

But anyway, everything has changed. Sewing at home is a hobby really. The majority of people buy ready-made clothes in the shops. We think that the same trend might happen in everything related to food. And if I ask you how many of you can cook? Well, men and women would raise their hands, and I would raise my hand. I know how to cook, but this is going to change. And we see how this food services and delivery services are growing. They're growing rapidly. So we could not ignore this industry that is soaring. Entertainment, people are more and more dependent on their mobile devices. It is hard to get their attention outside of their smartphones. So we need to make sure that people who spend all this time on entertainment can use our services, too.

Mobility, that's a very promising industry. We are actively participating in this area. We have great services for public transport. For public transport, you can pay for your commute on -- with a card. So Sberbank is one of the major players on the mobility market. But if you look at other mobility services like travel, with Spasibo loyalty points program you can enter the Spasibo portal, and you can buy air tickets or train tickets. And this is much more beneficial than to be a member of some loyalty programs for -- provided by some hotels and carriers.

Now I'm not going to talk about the Russian companies. I had miles of some American company -- air company, and they said, "You can use these points to go to this specific city on Thursday, but you cannot buy the tickets for tomorrow." You can use these Spasibo loyalty points to pay for any hotel and any ticket. You know that we're actively working to close our deal with Mail.ru Group. I say that we have an ambition to close it by the end of the year. We're in final stages now. And after the deal is sealed, we will have absolutely new services, Citymobil taxi and YouDrive car sharing service, that is going to be actually development, and that is delivering this mobility service. That is very important. Now the figures that I showed you, just to make sure everyone is on the same page, these figures are the forecast for the end of the year. So our investments in the joint ventures with Mail.ru are there.

Now safety and security. That's insurance services, health care services, biometric services that helps to protect people from cyber fraud, cybersecurity. And a major problem and challenge many people face is how to find a proper job. According to surveys, 80% of employed people think of moving to another place. That means that every 3 or 4 people present here would consider another place, another employer. So these services should provide this opportunity. And if you talk about our potential clients, corporate clients of our ecosystems, what businesses need?

Businesses need 3 major elements: how to increase sales, how to cut costs and how to mitigate risks. And we are targeting these 3 major business needs, and we want to offer very good tools to promote their business. As I said before, the majority of the services in our ecosystems are aggregators or marketplaces that try to make sure that you can grow your sales as a company. Cost cutting, well, obviously, Sberbank offers services -- affordable services with good value. And this is -- this would help you to optimize costs. As for risk mitigation, we deliver the services here, too. And all that means that we span across the major needs of the businesses and that we are attractive to our corporate customers.

Now I would like to talk about our company -- specific companies and move from this general presentation. These are the companies who are participants of our ecosystem. These are the 4 largest companies: Yandex. Market, Rambler, Citymobil and Delivery Club. Today, we are going to have a deep dive presentations about these companies. I will give the floor to the heads of these companies later. I would like to talk about some of the companies that we have not mentioned before to give you some color in terms of how they work and how they are being developed.

I'll start with SberFood. This is a service delivered with our joint venture with Mail.ru. It is based on these siloed services that we had like Plazius, Afisha. Restaurants. This service was launched on 28th of October 2019. Now we have around 500,000 monthly active users. We have thousands of bookings that is on daily, and more than 2,000 restaurants have been connected. The important thing to understand is that now restaurants move to a new model. The model used to be the following: you would be able to book a table and get some loyalty points or discounts. Now there is a better model. It gives you a kind of an Uber experience but for the restaurants.

That means that when you finish with your meal, you don't need to wait for a waiter. You just stand up and go, and all the payments will be done automatically, the tips included. This is a very in-demand service. And one of the screen shows that you can split the check at the restaurant between those -- between your friends who are with you at the restaurant. And another important thing is that, together with Mail.ru, we integrated all our services. In SberFood, you have an option. Like you have selected restaurant, but then you have thought, "I don't want to go there." But you can push Delivery Club button, and the restaurant will come to your place, and you will enjoy the restaurant food from the comfort of your sofa.

Another important project of our joint venture with Mail.ru is SberMarket. It was launched on the 11th of November, just 1 month ago. It was launched based on Instamart service. November saw a radical acceleration of growth, 4.5x growth compared to the same period of the previous year. Works in 16 cities in the Moscow region, and it works in 15 largest cities of Russia. It is developing quite rapidly because this business has a great potential, and I believe that in 2020 the growth rate is going to be at least the same as we see them -- as we see right now.

David expanded on SberCloud, but we see SberCloud not only as a technical opportunity, but a business opportunity. We see a great potential in this product. We launched this product in test mode in summer this year. But in 2020, it will host 130 -- up to 150 products. And we think the B2G customers, meaning the state authority customers and the business customers will actively use this service. And we will suggest and offer bundles where SberCloud services would be bundled with our banking and nonbanking products.

Cybersecurity. We are totally obsessed with cybersecurity and security of data. We repel, touchwood, all attacks -- cyberattacks that were launched against Sberbank. But cybersecurity is not only an opportunity to protect yourself, but an opportunity to protect others. So several years ago, I think 3 years ago, we founded a company called BI. ZONE. It's -- it was started from scratch, from greenfield. We didn't acquire any other companies. This is a cybersecurity company. Now it is experiencing a radical growth, not only on the Russian market, but on international market, too. This year, around half of the revenue is accounted for by our international customers. I think that, next year, the growth rate for this business is going to accelerate, and the share of services that we deliver in Russia is going to decrease because these services are in demand across the world. And Russia is quite a small market.

Now 2 services in biometry, one is VisionLabs and the other one is CRT. I'll start with CRT. This business is our joint venture with Gazprombank. This business is actively growing. It is a leading company in terms of voice recognition, Center for Voice (sic) [of Speech] Technologies. This is how CRT -- this is what the CRT abbreviation stands for. And there are new services that we deliver for the doctors. A doctor in stand of spending huge amounts of time to read the scans or to read the information or to type the information, that is the yesterday. The machine would get the voice-to-text technology, and it will save a lot of time for our doctors, so that they spend more time with the customers or with the patients.

And VisionLabs is top 1 company in -- according to National Institute of Standards and Technology. That's an American association. So this is a company that is not only the best in Russia but the best in the world in terms of the face recognition algorithm. They got it for accuracy and speed. It is growing. The revenue is growing with more than 100% year-on-year. And you know that Sberbank went to devices market. And you know that smart devices like Evotor conquered the market. It is the most popular smart terminal across the country, and it has a great gap -- the competition is -- has a great gap lagging behind.

Now another product that I would like to show you, out-of-the-box product. Can I get the box? Can I get the box, too? So this is a device that has been produced. It is a vandal protection -- protected lab. It is a device from our -- developed from our VisionLabs and BI. ZONE, so you cannot hack it. It can work in offline and online mode. It can store up to 500,000 photos. It is an industrial product. It is for the companies. You cannot buy it freely. But for companies who want -- who need to manage access to their properties and facilities, this product will be interesting. You can look at this product in -- during the coffee break. I think that we did a great job in terms of the design, starting from the box to unbox and experience, and everything is in line with the best practices of the Silicon Valley.

Going on, SberMobile, our mobile operator. There are many discussions around it. But if you remove the emotions and focus on the figures, you see the following. We're actively growing our customer and subscriber base. At the start of the year, we started the regional expansion. And as you can see from 165,000, we moved to 850,000 subscribers. That was done in only 1 year, and our growth is done not only through marketing campaigns. And it is not done through the burning of the money spent for the ads. And if you calculate the price of 1% of the market share across the market, it's 7.5x lower for us than for the average telecom company in Russia gaining this 1% market share. So we are going to develop SberMobile, and we hope that it will be relevant for our customers.

Sber Solutions is a company that we have acquired last year. This is one of the few examples when we bought the entire company, 100%. It is a company that works for the outsourcing of business processes. This is a B2B subscription that investors love. This is when customers are stuck with the service. So this service is used as a window, as a portal. The company enters this portal. And the more user -- the better user experience the company has, the less they want to go out to abandon the service. So you can see the market share is growing. And we cater for companies working in 30 different industries. Next year, Sber Solutions are going to offer products -- various products for small businesses and for municipal and federal agencies.

I move into the end of my presentation. In 2017, when we presented our strategy, we stated that we -- our target is to make sure that in 2020, our revenue from nonbanking services would be not less than RUB 70 billion. I would like to underline that this is the revenue from nonbanking revenue. This is our revenue, revenue attributable to Sberbank only, without our partners. I think if we accounted for our partners, it'll be more than RUB 150 billion. But we said that our share would be RUB 70 billion. We're quite confident in -- on delivering on this commitment. And this does not include fee and commissions that Sberbank gets from promoting all services. This part of the income is accounted in the P&L of Sberbank.

Before going to the companies' presentations, I would like to say that we understand that some companies in the ecosystem have great potential, including great potential for IPO. We understand that there are some limitations for Sberbank in terms of putting companies to the market with -- where the share of Sberbank is more than 50% due to the geopolitical and sanction situation. So the companies who are IPO candidates, we have large stakes there, but not the controlling stake. And all these companies, all these partners, have a great potential to move to IPO in 3, 5 years.

And now I would like to move back to what I promised. And I would like to give the floor to Maksim Grishakov. He's going -- he's the CEO of Yandex. Market. This is our joint venture with Yandex. After that, you'll have a deep dive delivered by CEO of Rambler, the Head of Citymobil and Delivery Club. And after that, we're going to have a Q&A session. We'll try to answer your question. So Maksim, the floor is yours.

MAKSIM GRISHAKOV, CEO OF YANDEX.MARKET, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: Yes, Lev. Thank you very much. Dear, ladies and gentlemen, again, good morning. Actually, it's my great privilege to address you on the performance of Yandex. Market as an inherent part of the Sberbank ecosystem. I'm going to try to be very brief because the organizers asked me to speed up, we are a bit behind schedule.

Let me speak a little bit about the market of e-commerce in Russia. The consensus is -- the consensus evaluation is that, in 2019, the market is going to have about 390 orders -- 390 million orders. And the average ticket, about RUB 4,000. Sometimes the tickets are very small in FMCG, for instance, or there are huge tickets in electronics, household appliances. But the average AOU -- AOV is about RUB 4,000. The growth of e-commerce has been continuing and has actually been accelerating. It's a pretty promising area. Generally, we see retail sales growing by several digits of percent, while e-commerce has been growing by 15% to 20%. And the promise is very, very strong for accelerated growth.

Very briefly, what Yandex. Market is. We have a 2 shareholder structure, equitable shareholders: Yandex and Sberbank. And there are several platforms, Yandex. Market as the local e-commerce market; Beru, the new platform; and there's a few experiments that are the new streams for us for the future development. The history of our development is pretty simple. And on 27th of April last year, we signed the new deal, where we got the new shareholder in the person of Sberbank. In May, we launched a beta of Beru. That was an experiment that pretty quickly went to a full-fledged operation. In October 2018, we officially launched Marketplace. I remember about a year ago I addressed the same audience of analysts of Sberbank, but that was more of a promise.

When I spoke about Beru, we spoke about the plans and the objectives. Today, I'm here to speak about the performance. And they -- and that performance is actually well above our expectations, and we have been continuing to grow. In 2019, in December, we launched our first own fulfillment center in Rostov. Then we relaunched the aggregator of last mile delivery services, Yandex. Lavka. In May 2019, we launched experiment with our automated disbursement points, the so-called post box machines. Again, later, we, in June, launched Supercheck. That's what Yandex. Market did online, but that's done for offline.

In July, we finished the integration with Sberbank ID. Right now, Sberbank clients can seamlessly log in with Beru and Yandex. Market. And in November this year, at the peak of e-commerce season, we launched our own warehouse in Sofia. That's about 38,000 square meters of storage. Again, Yandex. Market is a product that's a price comparison product platform, as we call it. There's about 30,000 online stores, about 35 million SKUs and 65 million product offerings as a whole. And the daily audience is about 3.5 million customers. Customers, the monthly audience is about 40 million. And on the peak, it's about 5 million users a day. In Beru, Beru actually did a revolutionary -- accomplished revolutionary growth from scratch. This year, we'll probably be in the top 10 of major online retailers. We've got about 1 million SKUs on the platform, our own products and the Marketplace products. Right now, we are delivering about 40,000, maybe 50,000 orders a day, about 150 goods -- 150,000 goods, products are delivered. And we accrue about 15% to 20% month-on-month.

Very interesting experiments are also done inside the ecosystem. The Yandex. Market Analytics, that is essentially the competition for companies like GfK and [SUNITSA]. That's only in online sales. We've got a lot of data. So we are doing certain analytical category views and offer those to vendors, to main brands. That is a highly relevant data, very popular. Yandex Dostavka, Yandex Delivery was relaunched on new technologies for online stores. That's an opportunity to integrate ones with Yandex Dostavka, and Yandex Dostavka is integrated with more than 20 last-mile services. Time savings and customer experience is much more streamlined.

Supercheck -- Superbill, that is a so-called scan-and-go technology. A customer can walk into a store -- brick-and-mortar store, scan a bar code on a product, just to exit and leave. The funds are going to be debited from the account. The pilot -- the first live pilot was launched 2 weeks ago in (inaudible). A couple of stores are operating like that. And then we have an agreement with a number of partners in chain, retail companies where that experiment is going to continue. As for the growth rate of revenue, we are accelerating. Last year, we grew just under 50%. This year, we're going to grow just under 3x. Versus the market, you saw that about 18% is a growth market by. That's colossal growth. That speaks to the actual popularity of the service. We are using our own technologies, the technologies of our shareholders, and we are doing everything we can to capture the leadership in this market.

Again, a few words about the Yandex. Market. This is a platform where people choose goods, compare prices and choose the online stores. This year, 26 million orders will be placed -- will have been placed using Yandex. Market. About 20 million is GMV. That's the turnover that helped Yandex -- that Yandex helped for the local e-commerce. Just as a reference note, if you talk about the internal domestic e-commerce, and we don't aggregate foreign players, this is about 25% of the market. That's the GMV created by Yandex. Market. And this is daily average usage, about 3.5 million on average for the year. We had upwards of 5 million a day.

That's just -- only several platforms and websites in Russia that have the same daily audience of 5 million people. The growth of Yandex. Market was about 30%. Again, Yandex. Market is not growing in hundreds of percent, that's a mature business. But this is still just under 200% above the average growth rate of the market in here. This is how the GMV is growing, just about 200 million is the GMV. And the orders are growing at an exceeding rate, by 30%.

What are we expecting going forward? What do we intend to do with the platform? Historically, the platform largely was about price comparison. And when people understood what product they wanted, they compared the lowest price or the most interesting store to buy it in. Right now, we are increasingly diversifying. We are setting ourselves apart from the competition. We are developing the choice of product. We want to buy exactly the product that people want, because very often, they buy the wrong product at the low price. The number of products is huge. So the huge UC content -- user-generated content, we are trying to help. People bought a lot of goods and help other people to buy the right -- to choose the right product and then find the right store to buy at end. This is one of the biggest topics that we are developing inside the Yandex. Market.

A couple of words to say on Beru, about 1 million SKUs in the platform, starting from scratch, pretty much. We are covering the length of breadth of categories, except for apparel. And some goods that are not allowed to sell online are alcohol, health. And we are not selling auto parts, and we are not doing temperature logistics goods -- temperature-specialized or goods requiring the specialist logistics. This is a trend for developing of orders -- delivered orders. There are certain seasonality elements. But versus the market, this is not really seasonal. We are mostly talking about the growth of the audience, the growth of average ticket, et cetera. To be effective and efficient, we need to control the fulfillment because our main mission is to ensure the maximum quality we want to deliver because that's the reason why we are investing in logistical capabilities.

We've got 3 fulfillment centers in Moscow region, 1 in Rostov. And we've got ambitious plans to keep covering the 1 million strong cities in Russia, where the -- all the orders are concentrated over the next couple of years. Next year, the highly ambitious plan is we are trying to bring the variety to a level of at least twice larger than now, at about 2 million SKUs, we are aiming to have. We are going to be offering the rational prices, optimal prices. We're analyzing the market. We're going to be suggesting the best price. We are obviously working on cutting deliveries short for all the buyers in Russia. Right now, we are covering about 25% of the population of Russia with the orders delivered next day. And next year, we intend to increase that percent dramatically. We are also developing the loyalty program. We are working with the loyalty programs -- our loyalty programs with our shareholders, Sberbank. We're highly -- we are operating very intensively with Spasibo. About 15% of goods on Beru are bought with Spasibo. We are very satisfied with this integration. We are highly -- we're very glad that this partnership was concluded.

As for the challenges, in 2020, it's obviously going to be infrastructure. In e-commerce, infrastructure is always short. So we are balancing between how quickly we can develop the speed of investment and the scalability of the things we already know how to do and have learned how to do. This is obviously the development of scope and scale. In 2018, people usually complained that these goods are short, those goods are short. Right now, the number of such complaints is going -- has gone down dramatically. Next year, I think we're going to cover all the main interest of our customers. And obviously, the same-day delivery or the next-day delivery is becoming the normal. And we are now catching up with competition, and we will actively fight for the leadership in this area.

As for the ecosystem -- I am running out of time, and I must speed up. We talked about the super receipt. We actually launched a true experiment with the scan-and-go technology. Great potential in the app because despite online growing at huge rates, that's only 5% to 6% of the entire sales. The remaining 94%, 95% is the rest. So the Supercheck is a product that is helping the people who are shopping offline. And if you actually walked into an offline store, we are going to help avoid the queue on the cash register and buy the good -- the product in the most convenient fashion. We're also working with a second shareholder with Yandex. We are trying to use the developments that they have been able to come up with, Alisa. That's one such development. It is integrated in Beru and Yandex. Market and users can use Alisa to order goods. That scenario is in its nascent stage. We are advancing it nonetheless.

Yandex announced recently this pilot project in robo delivery. When that test is no longer a test and goes into fully viable operation, Beru is going to benefit from that kind of delivery. As for Spasibo, we are very happy that we are having that partner. That's 15% of our GMV. 15% of our GMV is done by Spasibo. And we are working to integrate as much as we can with Sberbank partner applications, Sberbank Online. Like I said, right now, we have the full integration set up. If you have a Sberbank ID, you can seamlessly integrate into Beru without the additional passwords, without the additional accounts. This simplifies the so-called user journey and allows you to benefit from all the good things in the ecosystem. So much I have to say. I apologize for having to speed up.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: Thank you, Maksim. We're going to have the general Q&A for you, Lev Aronovich and all the other speakers of the ecosystem. And right now, we are passing the baton to Rafael Abramyan. That's the CEO of Rambler.

RAFAEL ABRAMYAN, CEO OF RAMBLER GROUP, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: Yes. Good afternoon. Thanks for the opportunity to speak very briefly. Let me tell you what the Rambler Group is. A lot of people remember what that is, but not the actual inside of it.

What is the group? That's a media business of other things. There's a lot of media assets. I'm going to tell you about those separately. I'm also going to tell you that it's a leading group. The market is divided into 2 types of deliveries, right. One of them is the 1P delivery, and the other is 3P. 3P delivery is basically what we send the order to the restaurants and restaurants are doing their own deliveries. That's 3P order marketplace. 1P is where we are collecting the order for the restaurant, but we are also sending a courier to the restaurant to pick up this order and deliver. And what we're seeing is overall globally, the 1P big rollout because generally speaking, 1P is causing -- actually generating better customer retention, better experience because the whole experience is better controlled with the tech and of the user -- the food aggregators' user platforms. This is exactly what we have been rolling out recently. And as you can see versus year ago, in the past 12 months, we have basically increased our 1P deliveries 7x, and that's one of the biggest reasons of our growth.

Now while you are talking about that, you might ask the question, what's happening with 3P and what's happening to Delivery Club. Given that we have been a 3 -- originally a 3P player, we have also seen that as we are expanding to 1P, our 3P business also accelerated. Why is that happening? Because it's basically creating better traffic and better user stickiness for us because, basically, customers are being able to access not only to the restaurants who have the own delivery services, but also with us, they are accessing to the restaurants who don't have their delivery services, thanks to us. So what's happening is more and more customers seeing more and more restaurants, and that actually explains our growth, which is 1P growth is also driving the 3P growth. And Delivery Club here is uniquely positioned as a hybrid player in the market.

And this is what I'm talking about in terms of the strong network effect. So basically, what we do is we basically attract more new customers. And then with our marketing and with our initiatives, we drive more orders. As a result, we are the bigger platform. And this is the positive feeding cycle and the network effect that is really driving the Delivery Club growth.

In addition to this, what we want to do is we want to go beyond access to all the cities and we want to provide this food delivery service to the customers of Russia. Ru is dramatically undervalued. On all the fundamental metrics, it should be valued higher. So the current market sentiment that brought down the price cannot be the basis. And this is a whole ecosystem, and very successful one at that on a whole number of areas. And for us, we are much more at peace if we have a much larger stake in that. Ru. But we have a very positive outlook of the market prospects of Mail. Ru. We think it is very undervalued, both in terms of its potential and their performance. I think people should reappraise their performance, and we're going to help actively. We're going to help Mail. Ru to develop as a self-standing business, as I've said, and we have a lot of overlapping domains. We have a lot of potential to interact and capture a lot of synergies that's going to benefit all our shareholders and all our customers, obviously. So thank you.

After the sale of DenizBank, 95% of the risk is on the balance sheet. Of course, Sberbank, we're the main risk-taker. As for the risk metrics on the portfolio, you're going to see that they are pretty much stable. Some things are noteworthy: Stage 3 loans coverage is 73%.

We often pre-provision, not when the loan hits 90 plus or when certain other visible impairment happens, we provision in advance. We generally follow a weighted conservative line. And so the dynamic of cost of risk, for the end of the year, our guidance was about 100, maybe 110 basis points. At the end of the year, it might be actually a bit lower than that.

As for retail, the cost of risk was a bit higher. That is explained by a change in accounting. We are now applying IFRS 9 methodology. This is also explained by the fact that the risk in this market, in the unsecured lending market, went a bit higher. The corporate lending, quite obviously, the shrinkage of cost of risk is a decrease explained by one-off unwinding of Agrokor provisions. For the next year, our guidance is going to be 100, maybe 110 bps. We think that this corridor is a stable band for us for this year and the next.

As for RWA density, there are always a lot of questions on that. This year, perhaps the most important one-off that affected it, those were the macro prudential cushions introduced by the Central Bank. We decided to reflect those in our IFRS capital adequacy report that already led to the increase of RWA density this year. In the fourth quarter, there will be a slight growth as well. And next year, we expect the macroprudential cushions will continue to negatively affect RWA density because the loans are going to be amortizing and the new loans are going to be coming in with new weights.

Also, as an IRB bank, we see those cushions a bit less than the rest of the banking system for -- so for similar banks, RWA is actually higher. This is the estimate we see for the end of the year: 97%. Yet, I have to say, I have to add that right now we filed several things with the Central Bank for the retail and the corporate business segments. And we had a rather positive discussion with the Central Bank already this year. We expect the approvals on those requests, and there's even a scenario we're under -- already this year, we're going to get the approval, the final approval, for using new models. In this case, we will materially improve RWA density, but because there's very little time left until the end of the year, there is a strong chance that that's going to happen next year in the first quarter.

Also next year, we will continue transitioning to IRB, transitioning other segments to IRB. In light of certain specificity of the segments, I don't expect any material unwinding of RWA. The effect is probably going to be neutral. Having said that, we are discussing a transition to Basel 3.5 with the Central Bank. And SMA on operating risk, that is also on the cards. If you factor all that in, the already existing requests, Basel 3.5 and the potential transition to SMA, I expect our RWA density to be around 93%.

Now as for the corporate loan portfolio, you saw those dynamics. The absolute volume of the portfolio in foreign exchange fell since 2016. If you look at the share of foreign exchange versus the rest of the portfolio, it actually fell deeper. In the credit policy, we designated quite clearly that foreign exchange lending is only subject to the existence of actual foreign exchange revenue, so I don't really expect that share to grow. As for the retail portfolio, it has been growing at a rather quick pace. And we are seeing that the risk that is formed in our portfolio that is materially and sometimes several multiples better than the risk in the rest of the banking system.

We have not -- we did not show that before, but this shows the dynamic on the digital metrics in the retail lending process. The white tables, that's the things that we do in digital channels. The light blue, that's the loans approved on the 0/11 fields technology, either no questionnaire at all or a very brief questionnaire. And the deep blue, that's the share of the loans that we decide in real time. That's about 2 minutes. In 2014, we did not use to have those technologies. At this time, all these metrics are pretty high up. The share of loans in digital channel at 71%, that's customer channels -- that's customer choice. 71% of customers come to the digital channels. So those metrics -- this metric is going to depend on customer behavior.

As for the other 2 metrics, this is our technology that allows us to make decisions, on one hand, close to real time, 90% of the traffic, and 80% of the customers don't fill in any fields in the questionnaire. And the target is obviously make it 100%, but that will probably be never achieved. There are always certain exceptions, some more complicated loans to make. I don't think both of these metrics are going to go way above 90%. And the goal is to move closer to 100% level.

As for the PTI, as the question that is quite often asked, we see the growth of the PTI for our portfolio. Recently, the Central Bank has issued an analytical report on the loan lending burden for the retail customers, so they see that the burden is going nearer to the levels of 2014. We think that the PTI is not the only metric that shows you the creditworthiness of a customer, and we see some new opportunities in retail. Given the risk that we have, given the fact that we use multiple models, not only the PTI metric, we see huge opportunities, quite large opportunities on this market.

I'll skip some of the slides to save time. This is the mortgage portfolio, the LTV for mortgage portfolio. And an interesting thing here is NPL90+ on the 12th payment installment, depending on the LTV at the issuance. Thanks to strategy, we maintain and manage the risk, and the risk for LTV that's higher than 80% is sometimes even lower than compared with other categories of LTV.

Talking about the collection, quite stable metrics here. They're quite high, still quite high. And as for the retail lending, we see the growth of hazards in NPL90+ for the entire portfolio. This metric is growing across the banking system. It is growing, and across the banking sector, it is 2x higher.

Now I'd like to talk about our lending opportunities and capacity. This year, we have made a record-high number of loans approved. 403,000 applications were reviewed. That is 2x higher than the previous record. It's not only about -- the thing is not about the capacity. The thing is about the fact that we are using a totally new architecture that helps us to process a lot of transactional data online. And these are heavy data, and we can use complicated models. And this technology is scalable. So we do not rule out the opportunity, the possibility of our capacity would grow double-fold. Actually, we're not even -- we even target the double-fold growth here.

We use various models and strategies and approaches. In risk management, we're not only working with data and models, we're applying different strategies. We use different models for interest rate and limit determination. There are the entire cascades of models that are used that help us to ensure the good combination of risk and yields. The use of all of these models and approaches helped us to drive down the manual labor. And this 90% of near-real-time decisions for 400,000 applications is basically, of course, the result of the working model and working strategy and has helped us to reduce the headcount three- or fourfold, 3 or 4x yet.

We have a new role: fraud analyst. So in the loan portfolio, we don't look at the application, the specific application. We look at the level of fraud, and we analyze the incoming flow. So this figure is going to go down, and this figure is going to go up. As for the corporate lending process for small and micro businesses, we have -- we implemented last year an approach that we called the digital Evergreen limits. This is a technology that helps to determine limits for customers. 2 million SME companies in Russia have these limits. And basically, businesses can select the customers with whom they want to work from a huge pool of customers. The pool of customers with whom you can work is 2 million. And the share of automated decisions within this process is quite high. Currently, it's 15%, and it is going to grow further. That's it for me, and I'm ready for questions. Thank you.

Questions and Answers

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Just 3 questions. I think we'll have time for 3 questions. Okay. Andrey has a question, Olga and Mikhail.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: [Interpreted] If you look at the performance of cost of risk for the first 9 months, as you put it correctly, there were 2 major one-offs, first of all, due to Agrokor reprovisioning and, at the same time, the provisions related to the oil refinery. But there is a kind of an underlying of cost of risk of about 70 basis points. Your guidance is 100, 110 basis points for the next year. It looks like a very ultraconservative guidance. What should happen again, some refinery problem again or some retail boom or -- because the PTI is doing okay. I mean what do you -- why do you have such a high conservative guidance?

DZHANGIR DZHANGIROV: [Interpreted] Well, I perhaps would not comment on the cases, on these specific cases. We're using the portfolio approach in our analysis, and these metrics are done by the calculation. So the idea behind that is the following: We know what is our portfolio right now. We have been giving rankings to the customers. So we have been rating customers for quite a long time so we have a probability of default and we might predict how the portfolio will look like in the next year.

At the same time, we calculate the loans that we can deliver next year. And we have the ratings of this lending, and this is how we get the metrics for the provisions. This is what we do. A priori, we do not think that there will be some major deterioration for the large loans. So this is the portfolio approach that we are using here. And actually, for last year, cost of risk was about 118 basis points. If it was not for Agrokor, it will be like these one-off effects of the previous period. The cost of risk will be -- would not be at 0.72%. I think that during the year, it will be higher than 0.72% though.

So I really cannot say that given the Agrokor situation and given the fact that in Q4 -- I don't have the presentation working. But in Q4, our cost of risk, when this decrease happened due to Agrokor, it is growing. It has been growing in Q4. It is going to grow further because this is the analyzed metric that factors in the Agrokor situation. So I expect the cost of risk to be higher.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: [Interpreted] Dzhangir, you can show the diagram.

DZHANGIR DZHANGIROV: [Interpreted] Here it is. You see, it was a decrease, steep decrease, and then it went up, and it is going to go up a bit.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Okay, thank you. Next question?

ANDREY MIKHAILOV: [Interpreted] Andrey Mikhailov from Sova Capital. I have the question about the loans to the military. I know that there is a discussion to write off them. And the Vice Premier who is supervising that is pushing for writing off half of them and the restructuring of the other loans, the interest rate of 2% for the next 5 years. What would be the P&L effect if such an arrangement is materialized? And is it in the guidance in terms of the cost of risk for the next year?

DZHANGIR DZHANGIROV: [Interpreted] Now you're talking about the military? Okay. We have quite high-quality portfolio. I do not expect these write-offs. Something that you're talking about is kind of a dramatically dramatic situation. We do not think this scenario would materialize. Any pass-through of the assets will be based on the market price, and the market price does not mean that you had that -- you said that half of them would be written off and half of them would be what?

ANDREY MIKHAILOV: [Interpreted] Would have an interest rate of 2%.

DZHANGIR DZHANGIROV: [Interpreted] No, we do not expect that, for sure. We have a high-quality portfolio. And write-off in 2% seems some incredible, fantastic figures. I don't know what you're talking about.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Thank you. Next question?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: [Interpreted] A question about PTI. On the chart, there is a growth of -- dynamic growth, 7 percentage points in 2 quarters. And your comment that you're comfortable with the growth of the PTI, does that mean that you continue to see a higher growth dynamic for the unsecured consumer loans? Do you have some expectations about this dynamic for 2020? And the same slide had a cost of risk in retail. Do you think the cost of risk -- will it change only in retail in 2020 against 2019 or in some other areas?

DZHANGIR DZHANGIROV: [Interpreted] No, I do not expect our PTI to grow that steeply. You need to understand that PTI in this period in 2015, 2016 and even 2017 was decreasing quite steeply in -- for us and for the banking system. In 2014, there was a devaluation of the ruble, interest rate hike, and all banks made their credit policies much stricter. And then they were much more conservative in terms of giving out loans. So this deterioration in 2015, 2016, this plummeting related to the stricter policies and the PTI in the system would be higher than this 40%.

I do not expect this figure to be -- to grow significantly. It will not grow significantly because we are nearing the record-high levels. That's the first reason. Second reason is that new macroprudential buffers impose great fines related to the capital. And for us, these are -- these effects are significant. And as for the other banking system, these effects are even more significant. So I expect the banks to make their policies stricter in relation to the high PTIs. As for the forecast for the growth of the portfolio for the next year, the Central Bank announced that next year, it is expecting it to grow by 10%. We have the same expectations: 10%.

As for cost of risk this year in our policies, we have implemented some amendments. We not only look at the level of loans with the burden, but we look at the growth of the burden. If we see that some customers have more and more loans, we limit the lending for those customers who have higher burden, and this burden is growing very quickly. I think that the retail growth, the growth in retail here will be on the level of previous year.

As for the slowing down, the slowdown might have double effect. So if the slowdown is -- there is a slowdown in -- the major slowdown in the growth of consumer lending, the cost of risk might actually increase. I mean there might be an opposite effect. So -- but I think that the level will be, in 2020, will be the same as the level of 2019.

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Thank you very much. I think that this was it about the risks. We'll have a large Q&A session. Thank you very much, and have a good day.
