ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted]So we have 2 more presentations, and then we're going to have a large Q&A session: Oleg Zamulin, the Head of Macroeconomic Research Center, and then we are going to have Alexander Morozov in Q&A session.

OLEG ZAMULIN, HEAD & SENIOR MD OF MACROECONOMIC RESEARCH CENTRE, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: [Interpreted]Good afternoon, dear colleagues. Well, given the fact that we are moving -- that we are not within the time schedule, I'm going to be very quick in terms of how macroeconomic trends, understanding that we are going to look at the global economy and the Russian economy, and this is the data that we put in our business plan.

So first of all, how can you characterize 2019 compared to 2018? Well, we know that the economic growth has slowed down significantly after the unexpected high growth of 2.3%. This year, we expect it to be just a little bit more than 1%. And the surprise is that the inflation that was -- the Central Bank expected at a level of 5% in the start of the year will be a little bit more than 3%. I would say that this year, especially the mid part of this year, was characterized by quite pessimistic expectations. It was related to the big situation in the global economy that slowed down. It was related to world trade wars and with the expectations of the global recession for 2020, now these expectations were somewhat mitigated. There's less and less debate and talk about that yet. So the global growth by the end of the year will be lower than that compared with the previous year. But for our economy, the other things were very -- were different and significant.

First, monetary policy and budget policy were tightened. There was a VAT hike combined with the tax collection. That means that a lot of money were taken from the economy. And this effort started in the start of the year. There was the lag in terms of state expenses and high interest rates that were put by the Central Bank at the start of the year. So this tight monetary policy led to the slowdown of the economy and then, therefore, slowdown of the inflation. Nevertheless, these negative trends by the end of the year started to materialize and go reverse. So we saw a growth by 1.7% of GDP. We even saw the increase of the growth in retail. That means that the consumers started to spend money, so that means kind of a revival of the economy.

The inflation, at the same time, did not respond. It is much lower than the target of the Central Bank. So year-on-year, in November, the inflation was 3.5%, but which is -- the thing that is more important that if we look at the current inflation, the average inflation level in the last 3 years, seasonally adjust -- 3 months seasonally adjusted, we'll see that the inflation is around 1% and the basic inflation is around 2%. So this is one of the major arguments in favor of the expectation of a further interest rate reduction by the Central Bank, which is expected by many analysts. But I'm going to talk about that later.

Now the budget policy. As I have mentioned before, the major blow for the economy this year was the VAT hike and increase of the collection of the tax. In 9 months of this year, the budget surplus consolidated was more than 5% of GDP compared to 4.6% last year. But last year, there were higher oil prices so if the surplus this year is higher than the previous year, given that the oil prices went down, it is a signal that the monetary policy's very tight. That was primarily explained by the higher income to the budget, and to a lesser degree, that was explained by expenses. Expenses grew, but to a lesser degree than income.

However, we also see positive dynamics here. If you look at the monthly spending of the federal budget, that spending was the lowest at the middle of the year between May and July. And starting from August, there was a considerable acceleration that only picked up the pace with every passing month. That is explained by the fact that most of the spending in the national projects, I mean there was a lot of gearing up to do. So now all those national projects are catching up, and the government is simply catching up on the spending that was underdone in the beginning and the middle of the year.

If you look at the regional budgets, this is a distribution of the surplus and deficit regional budgets, and most of the budgets are in the plus. But we see the number of regions in the surplus is about the same as in 2018 so there's no lagging behind the previous years. So we expect that by the end of the year, most of this budgetary driven -- budget-driven surplus is going to go away. And a lot of budget funds will hit the economy, which will also mean a certain acceleration, an acceleration of inflation within the next couple of months.

In response to this slowing inflation, the Central Bank, as was to be expected, responded with a really quick decrease of the key rate, 4 times consecutively. The most recent time was by 0.5%. And again, as I said, inflation is very low. And that's why a lot -- most of the analysts expect 1 or 2 further decreases, including a decrease on the next Friday. The argument in favor of lower rates has weakened considerably in light of the data that I've cited, the data on retail trade and on public spending. Very likely is a situation when the Central Bank simply takes a pause. Since expense has grown, it's legitimate to take a pause and see how that affects inflation.

Yet in our projection, we factor in another 2 decreases of the key rate, this Friday and in the first quarter of next. Yes, let's see what decision is going to be on Friday. I think it's going to be a completely unpredictable meeting. It's very difficult to project what the Central Bank is going to do. This is our baseline scenario. Perhaps the main charts are on the right-hand side. This year, it's going to be a 1% growth. It's going to accelerate to 1.7% next year; and in 2021 and '22, the economy is going to be on a more stable trajectory at over 2% growth. Inflation is going to be just under the target next year because it is pretty low these days. Yes, in the next couple of years, we expect it to be on the target of the Central Bank. The key rate, we expect it to fall down to 6.25% by the end of the first quarter -- sorry, by the end of this week, and to 6% by the end of the second -- in the first quarter where it's going to stay.

I'm going to keep this slide as a background, and I'm prepared to field the questions now. I think Alexander Morozov is going to follow. And then the Q&A session is going to be a joint one after that. Alexander, please?

ALEXANDER VLADIMIROVICH MOROZOV: [Interpreted] Good afternoon, colleagues. I hope we have not bored you to death completely. I'm going to have very few pictures but a lot of figures, so hopefully, you have missed those.

Very quickly, the first slide, this is how we see the sector growth. This is how we see Sberbank. On retail and on deposits -- on retail lending and on deposits, we see ourselves to be in line with the sector. The only aspect where we see ourselves a bit better is in mortgages and corporate loans as a whole. We think that next year, we might be -- we have a good chance to be just above the banking system as a whole and materially better than this year.

If you look at the structure of our balance sheet, you will see that the proportion of retail loans is increasing, which is great. The proportion of small business loans is also increasing, which is again very good because it's a high-margin product. On the liability side, we see the increase of current accounts in retail deposits without contractual maturities, which is the cheapest source of deposits, the cheapest source of liabilities. That is what gives us the best idea of our margin, interest rate margin.

And perhaps this is a key slide of my entire presentation. This is our guidance between 5.1% and 5.3% for the next year. This slide merits a bit more attention. Now throughout this year, we have been working on maintaining and rebuilding our margin. A whole number of factors that we analyzed in great detail at the conference calls contributed to a lot of pressure that the margin came under in the beginning of the year. The introduction of the IFRS 9 slightly muted the figures that we gave in the outset of the year. And the whole number of effects that we have been mentioning already, sometimes, the unwinding of the provisions -- provisioning in some assets. And those are big assets, they are quite big; interest income and expense was quite considerable.

But just to explain this swing here. If you take off the one-off effects, the margin should have been like this. Sorry, I do apologize. So if you look at what has been happening right now, since the beginning of the year, actually since the second quarter, we have been having visibility of this since mid-year and especially in August reporting, we have been rebuilding the interest margin. This will continue. It continued in November. It will continue in December, and we expect the peak of the margin -- interest margin to be hit at the beginning of next year. This is a very important statement. We are going to the level -- actually above the level that we've started this year with, despite everything that's been going on in the market.

If you look at the slide, next year, the income on loan portfolio, the corporate portfolio and the retail portfolio with respect to the mortgages, that's going to be decreasing inevitably, but that's going to be a managed decrease. Yet, we are seeing that this decrease is the same in the liability side, both the individuals and the corporate side. And because we are transitioning to the higher-margin segment of retail lending and the higher-margin segment of ruble lending, and since we are improving the overall loan-to-deposit ratio, there's more working assets. There's more -- there's a greater share of small lending and mortgage and non-mortgage and more current accounts. All of that really contributes to a rather high net interest income or better said, net interest margin multiplied by the accelerated growth in the lending, that has been shown in line with the sector or slightly above. That's going to be a better net interest income.

So in this sense, we are pretty optimistic about the next year despite the factors will continue to pressure downward. These are the factors like slowdown in unsecured consumer loans, definitely. The overall decrease in the interest rate levels. And obviously, the lower LDR, system-wide, and specifically with respect to foreign exchange loans.

On the rubles as a whole and the overall LDR at the bank has been growing, so our job has to rebuild slightly. And we see, at the end of the last quarter, that we are able to do. We are pulling up the LDR in the foreign exchange to that marker. Also going on, very importantly, it's important to understand that -- and I've said that on conference calls, we have been and still are positively exposed to the further decrease of the interest rate. The structure of our interest rate gap is that we are gaining from a decrease in the interest rate of a 1-year horizon between RUB 25 billion and RUB 28 billion in interest income. That structure is the repricing of our assets and liabilities. In this sense, since we expect a further decrease of the rate, in this sense, we expect the next year to be, in this sense, more fortunate for us. So if you look at our average NIM again, this guidance means practically, in practical terms, a flattish picture versus the current year, the expiring year.

Now fees and commissions. Here, we have a rather good, healthy growing business, healthily growing business. It was important for me to have a double-digit figure here, 10%-plus. Next year, we expect the same double-digit growth on fees and commissions. Despite the market reaching a saturation point, this is no longer the market where we started at some point. Despite the penetration of the card business has been growing, despite pretty much every quarter, if not every month, some new initiatives come up that are already priced in by the market and by the regulator, things to regulate are increasingly few, we still expect this market to grow, and we still expect further growth in transactions with cards and growth in the fees and commissions income related to that.

We also expect an accelerated growth in documentary transactions, trade finance where we are focusing. Our share, until recently, had been at an unwarrantedly low level. We are aiming to rectify this. There's a whole number of regulatory things, regulatory headwinds. You all know them. They will all affect the downward -- they will all affect down -- a downward pressure on the interest income.

Why we are showing it here? If we factor out these articles, other things being equal, apple-to-apple, the growth of our fees and commissions income is going to -- would have been mid-teens. So a lowering from the mid-teens to a 10%-plus, that is the result of the changes that have been going on or are the changes that have been expected with respect to the regulation of the relevant businesses. It's very important for us -- having said all that, it's very important for us that our fees and commissions income is increasingly able to cover our OpEx. 69% is essentially a level that we achieved and we intend to stay at this level. We do not intend to go below that. That's a very important figure. Actually, today, very few financial institutions in the world can boast a figure even close to this, never mind a better figure than this.

And if you talk about our share of fees income in the OpEx, of operating income, that's at least 24%. This is going to be helped by the double-digit growth of fees and commissions income and the lowering of our interest income. When I spoke about the interest income, that guidance is covering the year as a whole. Again as a dynamic, it is in a quarterly -- I mean quarter-to-quarter, it's going to be a bit different. There's going to be a lowering, but on the whole, we expect this to be like this, in this range. I am stressing this in particular because I am going to have all those quarterly calls, I want you to keep this in mind as the overall direction.

Now here's a few words about our spending. As we have said today, our spending on IT has been growing considerably, R&D. That spending comprises pretty much mostly the spending on people. You know that inflation in wages, on engineers and data scientists and AI engineers is pretty high. The cost of these people is internationalized. It's international. And the difference between the is there but it is still very strongly correlated, the cost of these people between various countries. And unfortunately, the market for the properly qualified HR resources in the market is not deep enough. And the growth of the business volume, the growth of the IT as our operating foundation that is leading inevitably to the more expensive talent and now fighting for talent.

Also we are migrating from legacy systems to new systems. That means that you have to run 2 things in parallel. And this is essentially a double cost. We need to appreciate that. And again, very importantly, you will remember that last year, we decided -- we made the decision that we had not envisaged in December 2017, that we need to change the accounting treatment of our software development. We transitioned into OpEx from CapEx about RUB 20 billion worth of spending, that was annual spending. Essentially, those are the money we spent on our coders that are involved in that.

Those coders used to be part of the Sberbank-Technologies (sic) [Sberbank-Technology], a subsidiary that we brought on board. And starting from the first of July, they are reflected as part of our HR spending as OpEx. In current figures, because IT developers are on a different figure, that's about 2 percentage points of our cost-to-income ratio. That's quite a bit. As of today, that's actually more than RUB 20 billion, that's actually above RUB 25 billion. That was a -- that was done on purpose so we can save on amortization and depreciation subsequently. Also we wanted to raise the accountability of the business managers. That reflected on the P&L, internal P&L. We now have a hard P&L between the business logs. And in this sense, it's very important to note that element as we look at the spending. So comparing these expenses with 2017 is not entirely correct because part of that expense in 2017 was in CapEx.

That said, we are trying to bring down our spending on all the others expenses, all the other operating expenses. And here, we questioned ourselves, how did we calculate that RUB 1 billion additional gain from AI? There's no single area of activity that would really bring you that RUB 1 billion. These are tens and hundreds of initiatives and I can only tell you about several of them. All of those initiatives are essentially -- I mean what AI is, it is essentially a redesign of the process in a way that the machine can rationalize a process to make it quicker, cheaper and more effective and efficient.

To give you an example, over the 3 years, just the accounting office that is structurally subordinated to me as part of the finance department, they are going to have a headcount decrease by 25%. And before that, there was a 20x decrease starting from 2008. So there's always an opportunity to do something better than you had been doing before. Is that important? Yes, it is. The same goes for the shrinkage of the middle and back office function, functions that are being replaced with robots. There's about 40% of decrease in headcount on paper. On paper, there's a shrinkage of 30% to 40%. We're going to be spending less on paper.

I can also say that we have been using models to improve much better, much higher, the expected duration of our loan portfolio. That calculated a much better exposure at risk. And because we calculated better exposure at risk and since we have this PD, and this is not a single point, but a curve that is growing as the term matures, we have an improvement on 2 parameters that directly affect the provisions. And that model was validated and that is reflected in our report, financial report already. You can look at the financial report that we publish. You can always find that figure in there, just how much the model approach saved us, and that only was enabled by the analysis of a huge data set.

I gave you an example of how we cut the cost, about how we diminish -- decrease the provisions. All of those methods have been validated by our auditors and Central Bank so we are correct in doing that. And that also helps us to earn because the application of models, as Anatoly was telling you, models are helping us to be much quicker, more precise and more on target in positioning our products. We can quote better, we can get better pricing on loans and deposits. This is largely done by the machine.

Now I can say that there is no manual labor in ALM, and it has been for a while. I use this word manual. Manual gearbox was replaced. Now a part of the margin is ALM, and here, we use modeling. This is modeling for -- that uses hundreds of models that describe various classes of our assets and liabilities. This is a dynamic modeling that we're using and it delivers the best option in terms of the pricing. So dynamic balance, something that has been presented, was presented last year, is being rolled out more actively and currently, part of our algorithms, their work based on AI, and it gives us tips in terms of where we need to make a decision to amend our pricing.

As you can imagine, the banking product range is huge, the number of interest rates that have to change every day. These are thousands of interest rates for this range of products. And machine is doing that, working with such huge swathes of data, much better than a person. It finds inefficiencies, removes them and gives the recommendations on the best approach.

This year, we launched the floating rates, something that has been already mentioned. We're gradually starting to rebuild our internal algorithms that can work with the floating ruble rate. And it also gives some additional positive influence on our fee and commission income. There are many, many positive examples like that. And if we put them all together, there are -- there is a huge number of initiatives from all blocks. But I want you to understand, that means better processes, better processes to earn more money, to save money and to cut costs on provisions.

And you can see it here. So you can see that the ecosystem is currently on the investment phase. We are building it. And our key KPIs here are the commercial success metrics, commercial efficiency metrics. These are the metrics that was set by Lev that are going -- metrics that are going to be discussed in larger details during our calls. We would love to hear your feedback. You can use our Investor Relations service for that. You could say what is a priority for you? What is more interesting to you? We do not promise that we would cater for all of your needs and answer all of your questions. We know that we won't be able to do that instantly. But we are committed to making sure that we gradually increase the information that we disclose. And we know that every quarter, we have some additional disclosures in information.

And currently, one of the most important priorities for disclosing information is the gradual addition of the information about our ecosystem. And as for the headcount, headcount without IT and experts is diminishing, its share is diminishing, as you can see.

There was a question about our network. I can say that our [14,500] branches have a very low cost-to-income ratio. This regional sales network, it's not only these traditional branches. But there is a structure of sales for the entire network. But IT, back office, middle office, risk, finance and HR management and product development are not there because this is Sberbank stand-alone. And here, we see the flattish picture. That's around 2 percentage point from that is the expenses to develop IT products that are reflected in OpEx, not CapEx. If it was on CapEx, it would be 30.

And then Sberbank Group, there is a slight increase of cost-to-income ratio. It is related, first of all, to the technology transformation and the development of our ecosystem. In terms of the technology transformation, I'm sorry to reiterate that again, but it's very important to make sure that you understand my message. We are moving to the stage of migration from old system to a new system. There will be a radical change of the landscape. So the old systems, legacy systems are still going to work but the new systems are working too. So there are service and cloud but we have to maintain and support both systems. And I know no bank in the world that would work in 9 time zones. And basically closing as banking day every day and doing that with such a great amount -- number of customers. No product, no service -- in no product and in no service, our share is equivalent of the share of the 5 largest American banks in their market. It's always higher. And if you look at mobile bank indicators as well, here were figures with [65 million] to [22.5 million] so it's DAU and MAU and 40% is the ratio. That's huge, that's huge. And that is -- usually, you can see that in high-tech companies, leading high-tech companies because for that, you need a lot of redundant resources and great investments in IT and the very important and huge infrastructure.

So these expenses, we think, are going to be temporary. And this helps to ensure the reliability of the systems. And reliability is -- it's not even #1 priority. It's like 0 priority, it's like the foundation of our agenda. And this reliability needs some additional expenses, which leads to greater cost-to-income.

Now capital adequacy, we closed the deal with DenizBank, improved the CAR. We confirm our intentions, starting from the next year, to go to the dividend payout of 50% from the dividend payout for 2019. As for the dividend for the period of this strategy, trying to answer your question that you might have, question will be asked when we prepare -- answered when we prepare our strategy for the next 3 years. And the dividend policy for the next 3 years would be an integral part for our next 3-year strategy. The strategy is going to be presented in November or December next year. Before that, I would not like to comment on that, but it is quite obvious that we do not forecast this level to go lower to the level of 50%.

For the model, that's enough. And Tier 1 capital, we're going to have around 14% by the end of the year. That's realistic, given all of the suggestions and ideas and innovations that are now actively debated in terms of the changing of the risk weights. This is our best representation as of today. What factors affect this figure? This is our sensitivity. Devaluation of ruble by 10% gives a great effect of 29 basis points and the change of the curve by 100 bps, that's 21 basis points and the growth of RWA by RUB 0.5 trillion, it's another 20 basis points, so that you understand. That means that we have a great safety margin in terms of complying with all the requirements by the Central Bank, including contracyclical buffer. And that's the figures by the end of the year -- relevant for the end of the next year.

And these are -- this is a very important component that translates into the reliability of our capital, and that means that we have a good capital structure. I would like to remind you that in the world, among the largest banks, there are no banks with a leverage of more than 11%. Sberbank is the only bank with such a leverage figure.

Our guidance, given all that has been said, there is a small increase in terms of cost-to-income ratios, a small deterioration. Flat net interest margin. Fee and commission growth, 10% for year, cost of risk, 100 and 110 basis points, and (inaudible) which was quite conservative, which is quite conservative. And the most important thing, return on equity, 20% as promised. And CAR, that's the derivative from it.

Well, colleagues, I'd like to remind you that we have met for quite -- for many times. And I saw that for us, the most important indicator of our success is the following: at any point in time, we deliver superior economic value-added, which is ROE minus cost of capital. We deliver it to our investors and shareholders. We do expect that next year, including thanks to your work and to your efforts and thanks to the Russian market that has more than 1 million brokerage accounts opened on the Sberbank, the cost of capital would be reviewed with the removal of the risk -- premium risk rates. And it will even more -- increase the economic added value even more.

And we deliver -- we have been delivering this economic value for years now and I'm sure you will be content. This return on equity indicator for me, I think is the most important indicator. It's on the top of the pyramid. But another important thing is to make sure that we ensure the good yields on the capital, the superior economic value added. We want to do that today, tomorrow and then long term.

We cannot promise you that we have this 20% all the time. If the rates go down to near to 0, then the interest rate environment will dwindle and that will be it. It will go down. But the economic added value superior compared to all of our peers is our criteria and it will remain. That's for sure. Thank you very much, and now I'd like to show you the last slide. Churchill said that there is no sense to say that we do everything we can. You should do everything you need to do, that is necessary to be done. So we take into account all of the changes of nature, weather, change in the interest rate environment and other factors, but the most important factor that we count on is us and our work. Thank you very much and I will be happy to answer your questions.

Questions and Answers

ANASTASIA E. BELYANINA: [Interpreted] Thank you. We're starting with our Q&A. Have many hands, okay, starting the Q&A session. Gabor, please?

GABOR ZOLTAN KEMENY: What a presentation. First one is on margins and growth. And if I put this together with a flattish or very slight drop in the margins which we saw, that would leave me somewhere around the high single-digit NII growth. Is this a reasonable assumption on your guidance?

And the other question is, I mean the overall guidance, I think is pretty much in line with consensus expectations. And consensus is a bit below the RUB 1 trillion profit you initially targeted for 2020. Can you comment on how you think about that target at this stage?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: [Interpreted] Thank you for your question. We have never targeted some specific net interest income. We always target the parameters. But if you combine all these parameters together, it gives us a double-digit EPS growth. That's for sure. And I think that's enough to answer your question if you look at your entire model. As for the second part of your question, we have never targeted specifically. Even when we present the strategy in London, we have never said that it is going to be this figure.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: [Interpreted] Could you please tell, RUB 1 trillion and RUB 10 billion or RUB 999 billion, is this somewhere in the other target?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: [Interpreted] If you look at the -- at 1% of deviation, that's RUB 10 billion. On the horizon of 3 years, especially these 3 years that we're very active, there were ups and downs in dollars. Everyone was expecting it to soar, they went down when the euro rates went even further down, although they were expected it to grow. When the landscape of regulation changed so much and continuing to change, when the behavior of the customers are changing so quickly. Is it real to -- on the perspective on 3 years to move in this -- within this margin of 2%, 3%? But we think that we will be near that. Our target was ROE, more than 20% ROE. That was our target, major critical target.

If you look at another thing, the dividend payout that we have paid throughout these 3 years, given the dividends that we'll pay this year, I mean for this year, this is going to be much more than we had in -- than you had in your model and that we have even in our models. That's the cash that the bank pays out. Now I would not want to -- I mean you worked greatly and you did a lot of good job. This is why we give you a lot of figures and we give you some wiggle room, but it should not be very, very large wiggle room. Next question? I hope I answered your question.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Sberbank CIB. You mentioned now increasing floating-rate loans within your portfolio. And do you have concerns that this is going to start having a kind of more negative impact on your loan yields and margins kind of given the kind of falling rate environment? And a kind of slight follow-up. In terms of the falling rate environment, you're basically still giving the view that this is the kind of net positive for you on an NII basis. Do you not think that at some stage next year, once a lot of the deposit and funding cost repricing has kind of come through, that there's going to be a kind of tipping point if rates keep falling, that your loan yields are going to start really adding more downward pressure to your margins?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: [Interpreted] Thank you for your question. I think currently, it's around 20%, the closing rate, I mean. If you look at the effect, it gives us the possibility to respond quicker. It will help to automatically change the interest rate. It will help to drive down the interest rate-related risk. And this is a more convenient tool for a customer and for us, too, in terms of managing this risk. And the possibility to significantly grow the loan portfolio in those segments that we consider priority segments for us in the corporate lending.

We have factored in all the effects, answering the -- your second part of the question. All the effects of the repricing in our model, we have factored them in. And this is why we're giving this guidance, not as a point, but we give a range in terms of the interest rate that I showed 5 10, 5 30.

urn:contentItem:5R6C-S3P1-JB20-G41B-00000-00Sberbank Rossii PAO Investor Day Strategy 2020 - Final2017-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexis121417a11058626.726Sberbank Rossii PAO Investor Day Strategy 2020 - Final

Corporate Participants

* Aleksandr A. Vedyakhin

Sberbank of Russia- Head of the Risk Management Service & Senior VP

* Alexander V. Morozov

Sberbank of Russia- Deputy Chairman of the Executive Board & Director of the Finance Department

* Herman Oskarovich Gref

Sberbank of Russia- Chairman of the Executive Board, CEO, President & Member of the Supervisory Board

* Lev A. Khasis

Sberbank of Russia- First Deputy Chairman of the Executive Board & COO

* Yulia Germanovna Chupina

Sberbank of Russia- Deputy Chairman of Executive Board & Deputy CEO

Conference Call Participants

* Alexander Kantarovich

JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - MD for Russian Equity Research

* Gabor Zoltan Kemeny

Autonomous Research LLP - Research Analyst

* Maria Semikhatova

Citigroup Inc, Research Division - VP and Analyst

* Mikhail Ganelin

Aton LLC, Research Division - Senior Analyst of Finance, Information Technology, Transport

* Mikhail Shlemov

VTB Capital, Research Division - EquitiesÂ Analyst

* Olga Veselova

BofA Merrill Lynch, Research Division - Equity Banking Analyst

* Samuel Magnum Goodacre

Morgan Stanley, Research Division - VP

* Vugar Aliyev

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: And dear friends, I would like to give the floor to my friend and colleague, Mr. Khasis, Lev Khasis.

LEV A. KHASIS, FIRST DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD & COO, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: Good morning. Good morning, dear ladies and gentlemen. Maxim, thanks a bunch. Maxim generally does the better part of the job, the larger part. Essentially, his part of the presentation can be considered the presentation in our technologies and the ecosystem, so I've only got a few bits left, just to give you the few nuances that she -- he fell short of time for.

Now why did we decide to build our ecosystem? It's an obvious answer, isn't it? Firstly, it's a global trend. And if we are a technological company, all the big tech companies build any case system around them. Russia is a window of opportunities. Why? Because global players have either not entered the Russian market or they did enter the Russian market, but they are still extremely insignificant in the overall lay of the land. Especially in Russia, there's only 3 companies that have been trying to build an ecosystem around them, 2 of them are tech companies that were native in tech, that is Yandex and Mail, and it is Sberbankthat is essentially a tech company.

In our opinion, we are ideally positioned to use all our capabilities for building an ecosystem. Why? We've got million of clients, individuals and companies. We've got a vast access to all kinds of data. We have got the ability to offer our clients any service at all, and we do not have to be the providers of those services. When Herman Oskarovich or Maxim spoke about the need to meet the end need of a client, our role is not in providing the actual service. Our role is to become the orchestrator on the relevant ecosystem and to connect the client, be it an individual or a corporate, with the best in quality or price provider of this service. And at the central of this whole thing, when we unite the technology, clients and data and the service providers, the greatest value arises at the focal point of all that, perhaps this is even magic and not value because bringing we know everything about the client and when we can anticipate the needs of the client, that creates this inimitable client experience that in our opinion no one of our competition can reproduce.

We are focused on the end results of our clients, individuals and corporates alike. We'll look at the end goals, at the end needs and not the ways to achieve that. Maxim spoke of the real estate example, people needing the actual property and not the mortgage. These examples are numerous to cite. We'll look at the industries, at the sizing of those various industries. We'll look at the potential in all those industries, some nonexistent yet, some already in observation. We have already set out on this journey. We already have several companies that have this considerable potential. Some of those are technical, technical companies. Some are strategic. But they all create this unique client experience for our clients and unassailable competitive positions for us.

We chose 6 very simple criteria that we base our strategic investment decisions on. Here is a very simple criteria, you'll see them on the screen. And we guide ourselves with these criteria when we decide. We think that our strategic investments over the horizon of 5 years, at least in 4 industries, about a half (inaudible) of those on which we're going to focus, we'll have to help us create the leading players in the relevant segments. The material potential it plays in real estate, DomClick.

The next business that we would like to give you, in our opinion, is the most promising business that we entered as recently as yesterday and with the announcement of the final signing

(technical difficulty)

outstanding industry in the United States and China. The leading commerce player is materially more valuable than the most expensive

(technical difficulty)

bank. In the Russia, the conditions are ideal to build a strong company in electronic commerce. At this time, the share of e-commerce in the overall trade turnover in Russia is only about 4%. Whereas in China, that share exceeds 20%. But the speed of change that we have seen in Russia will allow electronic commerce to grow materially quicker than in many other markets. And our goal is to use the next 3, 4 years and our joint venture with Yandex to achieve the GMV of around 500 -- RUB 5 billion. That is a growth of more than 3x. And we are convinced that together with Yandex and several other companies of the partnership with which we are currently talking with those companies, we will be able to deliver on this goal.

The next project that we're also doing with Yandex is Yandex Money. We do not talk very much about Yandex Money, and many people do not know what that is. But you will have heard of what PayPal is. I think 100% of the people have heard that. That is a very famous company. Yandex Money is both PayPal and Stripe, that's the leading electronic board and a completely unique technology of making payments online that makes entrance into electronic commerce for companies just as easy as it is done by the leading company in the area called Stripe. Maxim told you that we are striving to serve our clients in the future without asking them to carry any physical items with them, credit cards or smartphones. Several months ago -- actually it was more recently than that, we invested in a company called, VisionLabs and that's a top 3 international company in face recognition. On the whole, we think that computer vision will allow us to recognize both text and do a lot of other things to create a completely unique client experience for our clients. I'm going to mention client experience many times in my presentation today because he who wins in user experience and client experience will create the competitive edge.

The next area where we're going to enter is cybersecurity. At Sberbank, I'm going to mention this in detail later, is maniacally focused on protecting its sounds systems, the systems of its clients from cyber threats. We are a recognized leader in Russia in cybersecurity. As part of the cyber digital economy program that involves the leading Russian companies, tech companies among others, Yandex.Mail, those companies voted us hands-down the national leader in cybersecurity.

This year, [Basel], a company that we created in cybersecurity will have completed its first 12 months in operation. In this year, it has strengthened quite considerably. Its revenue is relatively small in absolute numbers, only about

(technical difficulty)

contracts. 90% of that money is external clients, and we are very glad that international companies are among those clients. Because Basel was accredited by SWIFT. It did sign the agreement with the Interpol, and we are in active contacts with many leading international companies active in cybersecurity.

I have to say a little more than a couple of words on another industry that is called digital medicine, e-health. What would be banks having in common with e-health? In actual fact, there's a lot. The first thing in common is our clients. They are all people that have to be healthy. They have to live longer because the longer they live, the more money we earn off them. Secondly is the data, and I can't pronounce this enough, data and the ability to learn from data is what sets one companies apart from other companies. Several years ago, Mr. Gref put this very important thesis, in my opinion. He said that the 21st century turns data into the new oil. Today, we see that our algorithms, the algorithms we use in banking, the solutions in artificial intelligence allow for completely different approaches to diagnosis to predictive health. When we answer e-health, it does not mean that we intend to hire doctors, that we intend to build hospitals. We want to be an orchestrator of this ecosystem. We wanted to connect the clients with doctors, doctors with health care facilities. And all of those above with pharmaceutical companies, there are huge synergies to be exploited between e-health and our main lines of business, both corporate and retail.

The wealth management has a lot of potential of integrating with e-health services. Less than a year ago, we entered this industry by buying the most promising company in the market, the leader in the e-health market in Russia, DocDoc. In less than 12 months this company, together with us has grown twice. And this year, the company has served over 500,000 clients. Its database spans tens of thousands of doctors, clinics. On the 1st of January, this company is opening a completely new blue ocean of business called telemedicine. That law kicks in, comes into force, from the 1st of January, and we think that this company has a huge potential.

Very briefly, let me tell you about other companies that we invested in and we find interest in. Avatar, the electronic cash register. Two main lines of business in Avatar. First this is the cutting edge smart terminals for small businesses. And the second, they are a fiscal data operator. Maxim mentioned the importance of knowing not just where the client shopped and how much he has spent. It's very important to know the composition of the actual receipt. And Avatar, that has only been recently in the fiscal data market with 26% of the market, that operator of the fiscal data is our window into this market. And it gives us a completely different quality of analysis of client needs. And this area has a lot of promise to its future.

Another company you may have heard little about is SberbankAST. And this is national leader in electronic auctioning. Every year, SberbankAST conducts hundreds of thousands of procurement procedures. And this year $32 billion were transacted in electronic auctions and tenders handled on this platform. Our mobile virtual operator and a platform to build end-to-end in IoT is SberbankTelecom. It allows us to save -- to have saved already RUB 1 billion by replacing the very expensive SMS messages with push notifications. And this year, we are beginning to deploy these services in a fully fledged format for the benefit of end clients that are going to be providing these services of mobile communications on a completely different level, having integrated them with the financial services.

Before we pass over to the platform proper and the technologies, I have to say a few words about another company of ours, SberbankTechnologies, SberTech. The figures are self-explanatory. Just think about it, in 10 years, we have been able to augment about 10x the share of IT development performed inside the SberbankGroup. This creates completely new opportunities because we've got the internal capabilities. We are less and less dependent on external vendors. And we can build our process, the process of developing software inside our group and do it quicker that allows us to create a completely different time-to-market frame compared to many other banks that operate in conventional modalities.

A small bridge to make from these things to our internal banking platforms. Very importantly, we create our IT platform of tomorrow that will integrate with our ecosystem. By API, we will be able to interact, not just with the ecosystem of ours, but with external ecosystems as well. Another very important element is the global profile that we are building for the residents of our ecosystem. This is Sber ID. Sber ID will be used by our clients to get access to all of our marketplaces. But besides that, we're going to be offering this to external ecosystems for a person that got himself registered with us to gain access to companies that will render their services to this client even they are -- even though those client companies are external to our ecosystem.

A couple of words on our platform. We have built this platform with the cutting edge things in technology. Everything that you have heard of about in-memory computing, about real-time decision-making, about dynamic pricing with prices defined at the point of contact for service provision, where the price dependent not on the things that the client did with us, but on the client behavior in social networks, on the client behavior in shopping, shopping history. And very importantly, this platform is going to be flexible, and it will allow for integration with both our internal and external capabilities. And this platform will allow us pretty similar time-to-market figures measured in hours that are, these days, featured by the leading tech companies.

We have significantly advanced towards finishing our projects in platform implementation. Next year, we intend to complete all the processes related to the coding of all the things on our platform. All the hardware is going to be in place. In 2019, the data and testing will be complete. And in 2020, the end of our 3 year strategy, we intend to see our platform kick into full capability including the connections with our ecosystem. This year, we were able to accomplish a very complicated project related to the transition of a material part of our IT developments to agile management principles. When our tech and business units operate together, we decided that not only we have to work together with Maxim as an agile team, as an agile pair, we thought that all our employees have to be agile, both if they develop projects, if they develop products for our clients and if they kill them. And that makes for a completely different quality of operation and that changes dramatically the timeframe for new product delivery and development. That will make sure that new products are taken to the market in the shortest time possible.

The overwhelming number of our developments are going to transition to DevOps. And we take particular pride in the fact that Sberbank's mobile application only came fourth, WhatsApp, (inaudible) Instagram in the number of downloads. We think this is a unique case when a banking application comes forth in downloads in the nation. Mr. Gref said that it has been 10 years since he assumed the helm of Sberbankand the team has launched all those transformations. We have traveled a fantastical path in those 10 years.

I'm going to switch on the next 3 years to implement our strategy. Until the strategy is implemented, we're going to shrink the number of people employed in accomplishing our operations by the number of 10 -- by a factor 10. Legacy systems are going to shrink by a factor of 1,000. And that will allow us over the horizon of 2020, maybe 2021, to make complete departure from the legacy systems so we can bring down the cost of owning of our IT infrastructure and increase dramatically the efficiency of our IT system in terms of speed and cost. Reliability is an area of other focus for us. We have achieved very big successes here. We brought down dramatically the downtime when our clients cannot use our systems. 99.99% is a very high level of reliability indeed. We increased 20x the volume of transactions that we perform. And the reliability of our IT systems is an absolute priority for our focus.

Now two words about cybersecurity. What it means for the bank. We think that we're not doing enough to protect our customers properly. We are the best, yes, but this is a focus for our attention. This is on top of the agenda all the time because the cyber threats are increasing. We are the awarded leader. Recently, we have received a award from MasterCard as the best company delivering cybersecurity. And yesterday, the U.K. Institute of Standardization gave us a certificate testifying that our security system is in line with the world's best practices.

We have created the entire ecosystem of innovations that includes, not only our internal business units that work within our functional areas, but the venture fund as well. And this venture fund not only invests in start-ups to get a good return on investments, but it also creates synergies with our bank. This is one of the tasks of this fund. And making sure that we have access to the cutting edge technologies, we have created 8 labs in the areas that you can see in the middle of the slide that are focused on resolving applicable application-related tasks, on making new technologies usable for the business. The accelerator that we are creating, internal and external ones, is going also to promote the use of creative ideas of our employees and external ideas alike to create new products and technologies.

Just one example. Our robotics lab. I'm not going to cover everything that it does. But this year, we started to test the cash delivery with drones. It's only the first step ahead, and our drone can deliver 3 kilograms of cash and go at the speed of 180 kilometers per hour at a distance of 15 or 20 kilometers. We -- it's actually -- it delivers real cash, real money. And we're doing practical testing right now. In the cash centers, we have many bladers or robots that are working instead of people increasing the productivity and speed by a factor of 3. At the same time, the precision of the processing is much higher. This is just one of the examples when the applicable down-to-earth technologies are used for our business and for our customers, but the major breakthrough we expect from the artificial intelligence.

The real maniac of AI is the Head of Risks Block, Aleksandr Vedyakhin. He's a real champion of AI. And I would like to give him the floor, the Senior Vice President of Sberbank, Head of Risks Block. He is going to cover our operations and risks and our achievements in artificial intelligence. Thank you. Aleksandr Vedyakhin.

ALEKSANDR A. VEDYAKHIN, HEAD OF THE RISK MANAGEMENT SERVICE & SENIOR VP, SBERBANK OF RUSSIA: Thank you so much, Mr. Khasis. Well, there is a lot of hype around artificial intelligence, just a lot of hype. When we understood how to crystallize hype and not hype, there are 2 stories that categorize, the data and technologies, process modeling and decision-making.

Now a few more details around that. Well, Sberbankis not a lake or a sea, it is an ocean of data. We have a myriad of data for retail customers and for corporate customers alike. And they intertwine with each other. We have all the necessary technologies to analyze these data. And I would like to say that our data, our task is to do a AAA, so data should be accurate. That should be actual and accessible to make sure that you can get them in real-time mode. And that means that we navigate through that ocean of data with a AAA rating. Well, at least for the data.

Well, just one small question. How many events happen in 1 second in terms of social media or payments for our customers, for Sberbankcustomers? Do you have any guesses, please? In 1 second, how many transactions, please, any guesses? Well, just you're analysts. 10 million, 1 second. 10 million, really?

Some other ideas? So yes, we have some room for improvement. No, it's not 10 million, unfortunately. But in any way, in 1 second, you can see 14,000 or 15,000 events that happen. And that is very important. That means that our ocean of data is replenishing all the time and we have an additional opportunity to move ahead. We have some potential to unlock. But it is very important to go along these standards. This is crisp, you know that.

Well, businesses used to argue a lot with analysts: Who is better? Who is smarter than data scientists? Well, analysts are smarter, of course. But anyway, data scientists or business leaders. But fish, fish diagram explains everything. Each person is important in his area. So data scientists and business leaders are as important as well, they are -- they are very important in their areas. We can influence that by proper decision-making. And the proper decision-making in asset liability management are the kind of decisions which affect our interest and margin. And that is the basic margin, the driver, [73%] to date. So approximately 5 years ago, we started cooperating with what was clearly risk growth, and that was when we started to have separate risk matrices trying to calculate separate drivers and the way they affect our decisions. To date, this is a big platform and I would like to tell you that it is already an established fact that this year, in 2017, absolutely, all of the interest decisions with respect to the changing rates and structures have been made upon a model analysis, model simulation, a comprehensive simulation of all possible consequences, both for the margin, for the profit, for the risk, for the capital, et cetera. Then on, we are delivering even a more comprehensive model, which in practically the real-time mode, enables us to simulate the overall demand and make it upon the social response models with the elements of artificial intelligence and with respect to all of this, is being done on grading. So that enabled us to make these calculations extremely quickly, not just in days and weeks, just minutes and hours.

Now what does it mean? This is 14 billion transaction simulations, more than 3.5 million contracts, 290 behavioral models, a whole series of them are self-learning. So what does it give us? That gives us something. You may ask now, is it too much or not to? (inaudible) 40 or 50 basis points. That is a crucible, a melting pot, and this is a crucible where we are boiling ourselves. The revenue, our spending on personnel is the same. But if you think about it, we change our personnel, we take guys from IT, artificial intelligence, data mining, et cetera, et cetera, these are different people. That said, the target to maintain the spending at the same level looks a bit more ambitious than it would seem. The CIR is going down to 30%, and the indicator that you have been perusing always, saying that your cost income is a bit wrong for you, you can't really mention that because your interest rates are high, your margin is high. Cost income, bring it down within 2 percentage points. We think that this is a decent target and an ambitious target by any measure, no matter what the margin is.

And finally, the fourth element of our equation is capital. In all honesty, giving out a return on equity in ['18 and '20] is much simpler when equity is small, honestly. The less capital we have, the better the return. We've got the limations. And our regulations are the limitations and the regulations grow year in, year out. We are mandated to augment our capital adequacy from one year to the next. It is a regulatory requirement. We have to meet those requirements at any point in time. We must make sure that we, with a probability of 99%, and this is a requirement of Basel committee over the 3-month horizon. Whatever happens, we have to meet all the regulatory requirements for capital adequacy. That's the way we see it. Let me remind you that the Basel committee requires that we calculate historical volatility for a period of 3 years. One of them is a crisis year, the year of the most recent crisis. So the buffers come up, the management buffer and the buffer that was approved by the supervisory board, the Board of Directors of the bank and the capital adequacy buffer, that takes us to a level of 12.2% -- 12.5%, which is about the European average on our scale and our size in 2020.

Sensitivity, very important figure. Let me draw your attention to it. The highest sensitivity we've got is obviously the foreign exchange risk. A RUB 10 of change gives us 60 basis points affecting capital adequacy, credit risk. Interest rate risks are quite material as well. With that said, the foreign exchange risk is the main risk and our model assumes that over the projected period, the currency risk is going to be rather stable.

And in summation of my presentation, I would like to draw your attention to the 3 traditional financial targets that we set until 2020, and until 2018 as well. We are consistent, no twists. We are consistent step-by-step, every day of improvement, every quarter, every year. Yes, you can see that we commit to the cost to income ratio. A very important statement that I'm going to make. We do commit that all the promises that we made on our guidance have been delivered on. We actually commit to further improving our cost income. Our net interest margin is going to shrink a little bit, but not lower than 5.5, this is the obvious upside risk. We do commit that our fees and commissions over the midterm are going to be in mid-teens. And in summation, this is going to give us a double-digit EPS growth, which is as important.

And finally, equity. We are going to be consistent in building our capital adequacy up. That, in no way, is going to affect our ability to consistently increase the dividend payouts, as mentioned before, and as Mr. Gref, the CEO and a Chairman of the Executive Board is going to mention in his closing remarks.

ALEXANDER KANTAROVICH, MD FOR RUSSIAN EQUITY RESEARCH, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: My first question is to the chief executive. And related to that, and I apologize for that, if you have any succession plan?

HERMAN OSKAROVICH GREF: Thank you very much for the question. I did try why the 3 years, maybe I wasn't as articulate as I should have been. We always had the 5-year cycle of planning. Unfortunately, what we have seen does not really make that time frame possible. We cannot develop a good quality document that will hold for 5 years out. The life has started to change very quickly. Technologies have started to change so quickly. The environment has started to change so quickly that this planning is meaningless. These are wasted efforts that give no added value. We have discussed this for a very long time, and we decided that the horizon, the outlook that we assumed is 2025. We try to glean the future 5 years -- or 8 years out. All our predictions, we tried to make in 2025. But the strategy of our own actions, we only planned 3 years out. We think this is the best practice for us. We're going to see how it pans out, but it is completely meaningless to hold forth on what we're going to be doing in '21 and '25 and '22. Thank God if we have guessed right all the trends, and that's a gigantic scope of work for the 3 years out. Actually, we assumed over the 3-year horizon that jobs that have to be implemented over 5 years in normal life, under normal circumstances. As for the succession plan, what Yulia has mentioned, the commitment of every executive to have 2 successors, that is mandatory for everyone, without exception. And as of today, we have a situation where every one of us, including me, has 2 potential successors. So far, I have not been able to spot any serious problems with that. Every member of our team is pretty much replaceable. Of course, you can't say that we are tolerant to a large amount of change as any company. We are limited in the volume of talent that we can tap and we are vulnerable to a potential huge departure of top executives. But if you noticed, last year, a significant number of people left when the VEB, Vnesheconombank, problem popped up. Sergei Gorkov had to go over to assume anti-crisis management. 55 managers, senior managers, left Sberbank, 2 of Vnesheconombank. And saying that we were badly affected in our development trajectory would not be fair. It was difficult to live through, but we did live through this. And we are glad that, now, there's another strong market on the team that is performing successfully. As for me personally, my contract with you is for another 2 years. I don't think we should make any wishes. I think, if we live as long as the end of 2019, we're going to see what happens. If you wish to fire me earlier, okay. You're going to have the opportunity whether you'll want to extend the contract with me, okay. It's too early to say that. We assumed all the excessive commitments right now. And you're going to have to decide that in 2019.

This is a kind of a border that categorizes the attitude to fintechs. And Russia, in this sense, is not unique. I think that in the next 3 years, the regulators will have to review their attitude in terms of the presence -- towards the presence of the fintechs within the entire banking business. Now Aleksandr Vedyakhin told about us migrating to a new advanced approach, and we now face the problem that is the whole number of models that we apply. These models work as black box. So within themselves, within these models, AI is used.
