If you need a longer answer, then one will have to give a bit of an explanation. So if you're willing, then after the meeting, we can give you all the details because there are some problems related to this. All right, let's not forget, dear colleagues, that right now, we are under sanctions. And there are certain limitations related to some subjects, which we need to pay heed to whenever we hear. Otherwise, there's a possible change in our shareholdership. One situation changes, quite possibly, our attitude towards it might also change.

YULIA GERMANOVNA CHUPINA: That does not include the risk of more U.S. sanctions on sovereign debt -- extended to sovereign debt, both new and existing debt.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: (technical difficulty)

maybe you can clarify that? And anyway, what is the probability that you assign to that happening next year? And how would the guidance check?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Look, you'll be better off directing this question not to us, but to those who produce these sanctions because we definitely have very weak capacity in giving a precise estimation of what these sanctions might be. The probability, the variability, which can be infinite is something that one should rather not deal with. You may draw up as many fearful things as you might, but it's very unproductive. We act on an assumption of the most probable scenario. Nobody excludes any black swans or any additional sanctions appearing, which is one of the black swans. We are -- certainly are trying to predict what our response might be to such developments. But I wouldn't really waste my time on such things today.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Here in front, sorry.

MIKHAIL GANELIN, SENIOR ANALYST OF FINANCE, INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY, TRANSPORT, ATON LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Mikhail Ganelin, Aton financial analyst. I have a question regarding your corporate lending focus. So you forecast 6% growth -- early growth and -- which is close to what we see this year. Am I right that you -- you're quite cautious regarding thought of credit expansion regarding corporate lending despite we see falling rates on corporate lending, falling key rate, et cetera? So do you quite skeptical that we will not see investment cycle in Russia or -- but only consumer financing?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Thank you very much. Well, first, we hope that you are right, okay? And it would be great, we would all win. Is there such a probability? Yes. We are currently in the electoral cycle, and we all hope that this cycle is going to end in seeing the reforms stepped up across the economic landscape. And it is entirely possible that the corporate portfolio will grow at much higher rate. For us, this will only be a positive. How will it pan out? It is impossible to predict today. So what we assume is the consensus projections for GDP growth and the ensuing monetary and all the other macro indicators, including the indicators for our portfolio growth, there's assume some growth in our share of the market. So any other scenarios are entirely possible, but do let's leave and see. I think in 1 year, we will be able to see and make more accurate and more probable projections.

MIKHAIL GANELIN: Cooperation with Alibaba, what is kind of status there because there was rumor that you came to an agreement (inaudible)?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Our agreements with Yandex envisages that over the horizon of 12 to 18 months, you do know that there are -- not just Alibaba, there are other companies, at least 1 major player there is in China who will continue these negotiations. We will make an agreement with someone, but making any projections right now is an ungracious business. Right now, this is a status that...

(technical difficulty)

VUGAR ALIYEV: Even if they're very willing to dance, unless you mind, I'm going to put the question in Russian. Vugar Aliyev. I'm from KPMG. I'm not an investor here. I'm just a listener, a person who would just like to listen to Sberbank's Strategy 2020. My question is not entirely connected with finance. It's more related to risks. Very interesting presentation that was. And I was really struck with a level of involvement that Sberbankhas exhibited on the implementation of AI solution -- solutions. My question is probably directed to Aleksandr Vedyakhin, risks and implementation. What areas of Sberbank's activities you see practical implementations of AI these days? What is the role? And what is the level of using AI in decision making? What are the risks related to that implementation? And how do you manage those risks? How do you tackle those?

ALEKSANDR A. VEDYAKHIN: You're not really being kind to me and I'm about to take offense. Where do you come from? KPMG? TPG? KPMG, KPMG, okay. Well, we haven't really worked with you that much. It's not just Vedyakhin that plays with AI. Lev Aronovich did say that he is maniacal about

(technical difficulty)

but only if only Vedyakhin does these things, then Sberbankdoes not have anything AI in Sberbank. Well, firstly, I do artificial intelligence. Yulia does artificial intelligence. Lev does that. Alexander does AI. Even Aleksandr does AI because that is a problem. For financiers -- he got stuck on one slide. For financiers, this is a problem. He showed on that slide application of AI newer networks for managing asset and liability management. I got a bit nervous, but then I rejoiced because moving financiers to implement AI is not that simple, let me tell you. There's another area of great bankers that find it very, very difficult to adopt modern technologies. That's investment bankers. That's a grating (technical difficulty). We've dealt with them, so telling them, explaining it to them that they are, a, not as great as they think. Yulia uses a term self-reflection. They look at themselves in the mirror and they don't see the cats, the proverbial cats that Alexander mentioned, but they see lions, all right, Whereas they're not even the cats. And this is a major problem. I think the ice has moved, to use a Russian idiom. Alexander said that 250 projects are going to be seeing the light of day in artificial intelligence. That does mean that we have broken the ice. This year, we've got just over 150 AI projects. In every single business block in Sberbank, we have a data science engineer. That is part of the data science community that Alexander and his colleagues foster and nurture. We have a Chief Data Science Officer. We have a Chief Data Officer that is in charge of data factory. And we have a Chief of AI lab.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: These are a bit diverse tracks of activity, but what that gives you is, today, everything in cybersecurity is built based on AI. There has been some mentioning about our security operations center [by zone]. Just one company, our company did that. That was completely impossible manually if the guys had not (inaudible) launched that engine based on newer networks. And this is great news because the bad news that this year hasn't seen a qualitative shift on the part of AIs -- on the part of hackers. Hackers have gone into AI. And the viruses have become much more dangerous and much more able to self-learn to clear the various defenses. And if we had not prepared ourselves, we would have been very -- in a very bad shape. So right now, this is an endless competition. This is a competition without any end to it. We have to be one step ahead of the curve. So yes, we are fanatical. We are fanatical believers in that the future of all the companies lies in AI. And the companies will find themselves on the frontier of this funnel of tech adoption, finance. These are data-driven companies. These are out-of-shell intelligence-driven companies. (inaudible). thank you. I can tell you about the risks, all right? Well, obviously (inaudible) and that is also very important to understand. So the approach to risk that I showed you, the MIT circle, that decreases most risks. Besides aggressive modeling, the validation business unit has been growing very strongly. The internal audit business unit is growing. They ordered both the modelists and validators. And now we are implementing a very good dialogue with the Central Bank, our regulator. They also have started looking for approaches to regulate the model risk as a fourth line of defense. And in my opinion, in the shortest time frame, the finance risk is going to be migrating towards more of model risk and AI risk. But this is just (inaudible) question comes, guys, how do you control this? And this is the focus of attention constantly. The other side is not done by us. The validators are always a separate business unit. That's what Maxim has told you for a long time. This is the very first part of mass personalization. This is all based on AI. The entire mass personalization, customization is based on AI. It's not possible without that.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: (inaudible) there was a hand up over there.

MARIA SEMIKHATOVA, VP AND ANALYST, CITIGROUP INC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Maria Semikhatova, Citibank. We're quite aggressive cost efficiency targets, so if you are in a position to comment what it means in terms of headcount and branch network. And second, what is the view on the market share, specifically in the growth areas, such as mortgages and CDs and credit cards? There seemed that all the initiatives you are taking will allow you to preserve the market share or you will be able to grow it.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Well, your question, the first question really kind of triggered me to give you a prompt response. Anyway, you want the hanky-panky or you want to go? What are you worried about, the number of our people or the number of our branches?

MARIA SEMIKHATOVA: (inaudible)

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: We showed you the super ambitious targets for cost income ratio. Why the hell do you care how much headcount are we going to have? We're going to hire twice that many people and we're going to expand the branch network 3 times. If we hit the CIR, why would you care? Why do you want to show that kind of an interest to this? Because I can't really give you an answer to this because -- and I would not like to take away from this

(technical difficulty)

And that's about 8,000 officers is rural network. That's 1 or 2 employees max. Sometimes -- actually, it's even less than 1 employee per branch. And if you look at the influence of how that affects the cost, the influence is

(technical difficulty)

the thing that I truly hope that we're going to achieve those targets. How are we going to do this? That's the second question. As for redundancies, that is again a very sensitive issue, as you will understand. But obviously, the number of people will be going down. The amount of automation will have to see some redundancies. We do build the ecosystem. So a lot of new features of the ecosystem and new objectives in the ecosystem will require the effort of retraining factory that Yulia mentioned. We do value our people because these people went with us through very difficult times. And they were imbibed. They are imbued with our culture. We learn to give the right skills to our employees, the right financial skills, the right technological skills. The most difficult thing is the change of soft skills. And if these people are steeped in our culture, we try to preserve them

(technical difficulty)

some locations, but we try to retain up to 100 people that do present value to us. Mr. Gref, if I may, I would like to add. I did try to take that message across in my presentation. Please, our CEO and our executives had very -- had it very difficult to get used to part-time. Part time, please get used to this, part-time will be one of the methods of managing cost. Please learn another 2 words. One is retaining, Mr. Gref mentioned that, part-time is going to be the second word. Yes, and also the second part of the question, the shrinking of cost for property maintenance, real estate. There's another transformation going on here. We set ourselves, again, very ambitious objectives to let go of the properties we don't need. But Maxim mentioned in his presentation, the intellectual -- the intelligent management system that allows us to shrink the number of management layers and the headcount involved in management purely is not that necessary. So we don't need that much properties. Last year, we offered this program called (inaudible) policies. And now we are pursuing that as a 2-pronged effort. One prong is we sell. Next year, we are supposed to sell in excess of 650,000 square meters, close to 1 million or a bit different on these figures. Well, it's between 160 -- 650,000 square meters and 1 million. Lev is responsible for this. So he's probably -- his figure is probably right. But this is a material downsizement of property portfolio. We analyzed our entire property network. We've got a full database of all our properties. Last year, we completed a complete inventory of all the properties. And we have a very ambitious plan to realize all of them -- some of them. The structure of use for properties is changing. We have to increase the volume of properties in Moscow because the headquarters was relatively understaffed as compared to other regional banks. And if we took a tech company, then a lot of people come on the disrupt element and change element. And that, as a rule, means increasing headcount in the central head office -- in the HQ. Last year, we launched 2 new offices, 2 new properties in Moscow, that's the new Agile Home in Kutuzovsky Prospect Avenue, about 250,000 square meters, a huge property, and a property in (inaudible) again about 70,000 square meters of useful area. This is essentially -- an essentially new quality of office space. This -- on Saturday, we open a new data center in Skolkovo. Instead of 2 years, we only spent 18 months in commissioning it. Over the next 6 months, it's going to gradually assume all the transactions. We're going to have a full foothold, 2 data centers, 50-50, the stand-by -- the stand-in capabilities is going to be [capped]so it can plug itself in hot. And the share of the market in mortgage, in credit cards, we have relatively high market shares. In mortgages, I don't think we're going to be able to build it quickly. We intend to maintain that share of the market at around the same level. As for the credit cards, it might actually see an increase, a slight increase.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I have to start wrapping up. But before I give the final word to our CEO, we'd just like to say from our rest of team that very much thank you for coming today. We will be on the road very actively after the New Year, so we'll hope to see you all wherever you are, in your home cities and home countries. And then after this final words, we will have lunch downstairs. And last, but not least, happy holidays.

HERMAN OSKAROVICH GREF: Dear colleagues, dear investors, our dear shareholders, first off, by way of wrapping up, I would like to express our thanks for you for coming. And the number of investors, we have an unprecedented number of participants in this strategy session, so this is a great honor for us. Thank you very much for it. Thank you very much for listening to us so graciously and attentively. We felt a very benign atmosphere. Understandably, we were very nervous. Today, we left this room about 2:30 a.m. in the morning, in the early hours because we tried to get the sense of the platform of the venue. We'd rehearsed trying to convey not just the figures, but the overall mood and the emotions that we feel while we work on what we do. The ambitious goals that we have set ourselves, you have to be a bit adventurous to set those goals. But firstly, I have said that we do believe that this is the right thing to do. And in all honesty, this is very interesting. I'm not interested in doing banking. I'm a bad banker. I do not believe in banking. And I'm going to do everything to take banking to its proper place. In the future, banking should be, at best, here on my mobile device. In the worst case, it shouldn't be everywhere or nowhere at all, and that's where it's going to be. It's inevitable. No matter what the bankers think, no matter how willing they are to grab the tail of a dragon flying off and the conviction of the inevitability of this and our interest in seeing that happen, in seeing the new way of banking, in seeing the nonbanking, but the client being the source of our entire wealth, it's understanding. And the ability to resolve the issues of the client the best way possible, that is what we find the most interesting. That -- that's what gives us a drive. That's what gives us all the ambition. And this is what really turns us on, the entire team. And we will do everything in our power to achieve success. No one knows how successful we are going to be. But the foundation that we have laid, as we think, does give us a good chance to achieve what we promise. So thank you for voting, your faith in us by buying, by spending your dollars and other units. So, a, thank you; b, greetings, Merry Christmas, Happy New Year. And on behalf of our entire team, first, do stay with us, so we can grow your wealth; and two, we would like to wish you very strong health, good luck, harmony and happiness to you and yours; and third, we prepared a video in summation. Hopefully, you can take away good spirits as you leave this room.

(presentation)

urn:contentItem:5XB9-PHD1-DYTB-K2K1-00000-00SC AG Alan Wilson one of 47 backing antitrust probe into Facebook2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisAbusinessnewsPg. 5SC AG Alan Wilson one of 47 backing antitrust probe into FacebookAssociated Press;

Facebook's latest foes: nearly every state in the nation, including South Carolina.

NEW YORK - Facebook's latest foes: nearly every state in the nation, including South Carolina.

A state-level antitrust investigation into the social networking giant now has the backing of a bipartisan group of 47 attorneys general, New York Attorney General Letitia James said Tuesday. 

The Democrat launched the probe last month with seven other states and the District of Columbia. It focuses on whether Facebook's dominance is stifling competition, limiting choice for consumers and costing advertisers more money.

"Big Tech must account for its actions," Louisiana Attorney General Jeff Landry, a Republican, said in a statement.

The group of attorneys general also worries about Facebook's handling of customer data, James said. That drew scrutiny after firms were able to harvest information in attempts to influence the 2016 presidential election.

Facebook didn't immediately respond to an email seeking comment.

The group backing the state-level probe by the seven states and Washington now includes 21 Democratic attorneys general, 18 Republicans and an independent from 39 states and Guam. The list also includes several states that cannot confirm their participation in pending investigations, James said.

South Carolina Attorney General Alan Wilson is among the 47. 

"Competition built this country and free and competitive markets are important for social media platforms," Wilson said in a written statement Tuesday. "We are part of a bipartisan group investigating whether Facebook violated any state or federal laws. To ensure that there is meaningful market-based competition, we will work exhaustively to verify that companies follow the law."

Facebook and other tech giants have also been feeling the heat from federal regulators. The Federal Trade Commission recently fined Facebook $5 billion for privacy violations, but consumer advocates and some public officials criticized that as too lenient.

A separate investigation, led by Texas and supported by attorneys general from 48 states, Puerto Rico and Washington is looking at whether Google is engaging in monopolistic behavior with its dominant online search and advertising business.

District of Columbia Attorney General Karl Racine, a Democrat involved in both investigations, said in a statement that he wants to ensure Facebook is "giving a fair shake" to the American people.

"No company gets a pass if it throttles competitors and exploits consumers," Racine said.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg speaks last week at Georgetown University in Washington. A state-level antitrust investigation launched last month into the social networking giant now has the backing of a bipartisan group of 47 attorneys general, New York Attorney General Letitia James said Tuesday.

Nick Wass/Associated Press

South Carolina Attorney General Alan Wilson. File Photo

John A. Carlos II

urn:contentItem:5VT1-VRJ1-DYG5-T07S-00000-00Scam ads for fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisYOUPg. D3Scam ads for fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookAmanda Seitz And Mae AndersonKingston Whig-Standard

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor - and sometimes U.S. President Donald Trump - to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist. While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly - and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads - they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 U.S. elections - and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation - loom.

"This is definitely concerning - definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it doesn't make that information available for other ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors'offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors'offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to reappear days after that complaint.

Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, N.J., 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw an ad claiming he might qualify for "free" solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release "$100 million solar incentives." He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be.

"It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people," Fitzpatrick said.

The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address - a mailbox in Carlsbad, California - that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company - then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough - for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records.

Akatiff settled the allegations without admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings. Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business. Associated Press investigative researcher Randy Herschaft contributed to this report. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Osprey Media Group Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:5VT2-TPY1-JC0C-J2T7-00000-00Scam ads for tax breaks prosper on Facebook Misinformation onslaught continued until complaints2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisAPg. 010Scam ads for tax breaks prosper on Facebook Misinformation onslaught continued until complaintsAmanda Seitz and Mae Anderson Associated Press

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor - and sometimes President Donald Trump - to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist.

While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly - and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads - they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections - and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation - loom.

"This is definitely concerning - definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it didn't make that information available for other ads until Thursday, when it announced it was expanding the database to include all active ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

urn:contentItem:5VSX-JWD1-JCMN-Y472-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookMAE ANDERSON and AMANDA SEITZ

Apr 02, 2019( The Today File: https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/ Delivered by Newstex) Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true. The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor — and sometimes President Donald Trump — to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more. Those incentives don't exist. While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly — and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads — they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner. Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads. The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections — and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation — loom. 'This is definitely concerning — definitely, it's misinformation,' said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. 'I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing.' AdvertisingExperts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms. Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it doesn't make that information available for other ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only. The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them. 'That allows people to do more dirty tricks,' said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program. In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them. 'These scammy ads have no place on Facebook,' company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. 'We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action.' AdvertisingFacebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies. Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as 'you can get paid to go solar.' Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time. After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, New Jersey, 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw an ad claiming he might qualify for 'free' solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release '$100 million solar incentives.' He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be. 'It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people,' Fitzpatrick said.The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address — a mailbox in Carlsbad, California — that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company — then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough — for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records. Akatiff settled the allegations without admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings. Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business.Most Read Business StoriesThough the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers. Scam ads are popular in certain industries, such as insurance or solar power, where companies are looking for people they can target later for products and services, said Peter Marinello, vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc. The scammers sell the personal information they collect to other companies looking for potential customers, Marinello said. 'That's how this whole process plays out.' Advertising___ Associated Press investigative researcher Randy Herschaft contributed to this report. MAE ANDERSON AMANDA SEITZ

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, New Jersey, 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw an ad claiming he might qualify for "free" solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release "$100 million solar incentives." He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be.

"It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people," Fitzpatrick said.

The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address - a mailbox in Carlsbad, California - that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company - then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough - for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records.

Akatiff settled the allegations without admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings.

Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business.

Though the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers.

Scam ads are popular in certain industries, such as insurance or solar power, where companies are looking for people they can target later for products and services, said Peter Marinello, vice-president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc.

The scammers sell the personal information they collect to other companies looking for potential customers, Marinello said. "That's how this whole process plays out."

urn:contentItem:5VV3-V9K1-JCP2-53JN-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisNEWSScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookThe Associated Press

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true. The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor and sometimes President Donald Trump to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist. While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner. Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads. The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation loom. "This is definitely concerning definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing." Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms. Last year, Facebooklaunched a searchable databasethat provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it doesn't make that information available for other ads. Twitter offers its owndatabase of ads and promoted tweets. Google has anarchivefor political ads only. The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them. "That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program. In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them. "These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action." Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies. Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar." Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them. Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time. After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, New Jersey, 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw an ad claiming he might qualify for "free" solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release "$100 million solar incentives." He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be. "It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people," Fitzpatrick said. The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address a mailbox in Carlsbad, California that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records. Akatiffsettled the allegationswithout admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings. Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business. Though the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers. Scam ads are popular in certain industries, such as insurance or solar power, where companies are looking for people they can target later for products and services, said Peter Marinello, vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc. The scammers sell the personal information they collect to other companies looking for potential customers, Marinello said. "That's how this whole process plays out."

urn:contentItem:5VT2-HWY1-F11P-X2TF-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads.

Source: Associated Press

In this screenshot made from a Facebook page, a search result for "solar energy governor" in Facebook's Ad Archive shows ads that were falsely promising social media users that they could "get paid to go solar." (AP Photo)

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor — and sometimes President Donald Trump — to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist.

While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly — and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads — they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections — and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation — loom.

"This is definitely concerning — definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it didn't make that information available for other ads until Thursday, when it announced it was expanding the database to include all active ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, New Jersey, 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw the ad last year claiming he might qualify for "free" solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release "$100 million solar incentives." He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be.

"It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people," Fitzpatrick said.

The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address — a mailbox in Carlsbad, California — that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company — then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough — for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records.

Akatiff settled the allegations without admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings.

Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business.

Though the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers.

Scam ads are popular in certain industries, such as insurance or solar power, where companies are looking for people they can target later for products and services, said Peter Marinello, vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc.

The scammers sell the personal information they collect to other companies looking for potential customers, Marinello said. "That's how this whole process plays out."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VT4-4MB1-DXVP-V3X3-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisBUSINESSScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookAmanda Seitz and Mae Anderson

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor — and sometimes President Trump — to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist.

While the ads didn't try to bilk people of money directly — and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads — they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scams and legitimate offers. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections — and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation — loom.

"This is definitely concerning — definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a created a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it doesn't make that information available for other ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to reappear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

Amanda Seitz and Mae Anderson are Associated Press writers.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VSX-0P21-F125-10GG-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisPMN NEWSScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor - and sometimes President Donald Trump - to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist.

While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly - and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads - they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected. They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections - and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation - loom.

"This is definitely concerning - definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it doesn't make that information available for other ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint. Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

After researching solar-panel options for his two-story home in Mount Tabor, New Jersey, 37-year-old Chris Fitzpatrick saw an ad claiming he might qualify for "free" solar panels because Gov. Phil Murphy planned to release "$100 million solar incentives." He was skeptical because none of the solar companies he worked with mentioned such incentives, but worried others might not be.

"It's very frustrating because it preys upon innocent people," Fitzpatrick said.

The Associated Press found that some of these ads directed people to solar-energy websites that listed the same business address - a mailbox in Carlsbad, California - that had been used by a company once under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, the government's consumer protection agency. In 2012, the FTC sued Jason Akatiff and his company - then called Coleadium, also known as Ads 4 Dough - for running fake news websites that marketed unfounded health benefits of colon cleanse and acai berry products, according to court records.

Akatiff settled the allegations without admitting guilt and agreed to a $1 million fine. Akatiff changed his company's name to A4D Inc. in 2015, according to California business filings.

Akatiff did not respond to messages left with his California business.

Though the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers.

Scam ads are popular in certain industries, such as insurance or solar power, where companies are looking for people they can target later for products and services, said Peter Marinello, vice-president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc.

The scammers sell the personal information they collect to other companies looking for potential customers, Marinello said. "That's how this whole process plays out."

--

Associated Press investigative researcher Randy Herschaft contributed to this report. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:5VT7-MYJ1-DXVP-V495-00000-00Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook;Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on Facebook2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:42ZLexisNexisAPg. 7Scam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookScam ads promoting fake tax breaks prosper on FacebookAMANDA SEITZ and MAE ANDERSON The Associated Press

Hundreds of ads on Facebook promised U.S. homeowners that they were eligible for huge state tax breaks if they installed new solar-energy panels. There was just one catch: None of it was true.

The scam ads used photos of nearly every U.S. governor - and sometimes President Donald Trump - to claim that with new, lucrative tax incentives, people might actually make money by installing solar technology on their homes. Facebook users only needed to enter their addresses, email, utility information and phone number to find out more.

Those incentives don't exist.

While the ads didn't aim to bilk people of money directly - and it wasn't possible to buy solar panels through these ads - they led to websites that harvested personal information that could be used to expose respondents to future come-ons, both scammy and legitimate. It's not clear that the data was actually used in such a manner.

Facebook apparently didn't take action until notified by state-government officials who noticed the ads.

The fictitious notices reveal how easily scammers can pelt internet users with misinformation for months, undetected.

They also raise further questions about whether big tech companies such as Facebook are capable of policing misleading ads, especially as the 2020 elections - and the prospect of another onslaught of online misinformation - loom.

"This is definitely concerning - definitely, it's misinformation," said Young Mie Kim, a University of Wisconsin-Madison professor who studied 5 million Facebook ads during the 2016 elections. "I keep telling people: We don't have any basis to regulate such a thing."

Experts say websites and apps need to be more transparent about the ads that run on their platforms.

Last year, Facebook launched a searchable database that provides details on political ads it runs, including who bought them and the age and gender of the audience. But it didn't make that information available for other ads until Thursday, when it announced it was expanding the database to include all active ads. Twitter offers its own database of ads and promoted tweets. Google has an archive for political ads only.

The partial approaches allow misleading ads to fester. One problem is the fact that ads can be targeted so narrowly that journalists and watchdog groups often won't see them.

"That allows people to do more dirty tricks," said Ian Vanderwalker, senior counsel at the Brennan Center for Justice's Democracy Program.

In mid-March, some websites linked in the fake solar-energy ads disappeared. After complaints from governors' offices, Facebook inactivated nearly all of the ads and several pages affiliated with them.

"These scammy ads have no place on Facebook," company spokeswoman Devon Kearns said in a statement. "We removed these pages and disabled these ad accounts recently and will continue to take action."

Facebook says it uses an automated process to review the images, text, targeting and position of ads posted to its site. In some cases, employees review the ads. Users can also give feedback if they believe the ads violate company policies.

Governors' offices were alarmed to see photos of top politicians featured alongside claims such as "you can get paid to go solar."

Helen Kalla, a spokeswoman for Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak, said she notified Facebook last month after staffers saw them.

Facebook took them down days later, although some continued to re-appear days after that complaint.

Facebook also yanked ads featuring images of governors in Texas, Illinois, Colorado, Arizona, South Carolina and other states. But the ads had already been running for some time.

Though the FTC can investigate fake ads, sue to stop them and seek compensation for victims, thousands of ads targeting select groups run online daily, making it harder to catch suspect advertisers.

In this screenshot made from a Facebook page, a search result for "solar energy governor" in Facebook's Ad Archive shows ads that were falsely promising social media users that they could "get paid to go solar." Hundreds of ads running on Facebook for more than a year promised that governors across the country had signed off on big tax breaks for U.S. homeowners who wanted to install new solar energy panels. But the tax incentives didn't exist. (Facebook via AP) The Associated Press This screenshot shows a website re-directed from ads promising big state tax incentives placed on Facebook. Hundreds of ads running on Facebook for more than a year promised that governors across the country had signed off on big tax breaks for U.S. homeowners who wanted to install new solar energy panels. But the tax incentives didn't exist. (Solar Rebate via AP) The Associated Press This screenshot shows a website re-directed from ads on Facebook promising big state tax incentives.
